item.title: Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense
item.description:
Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense
Intel’s stock price has more than doubled in the past five months, since President Donald Trump announced the U.S. government would buy a 10% stake in the ailing chip manufacturer, followed by similar investments from SoftBank and Nvidia. Investors are betting the new capital, coupled with a surge in AI demand, will help resuscitate the company. Those expectations will collide with reality when Intel reports fourth-quarter earnings late this afternoon, either making or breaking the rally. Intel bears say the stock has moved way too high, setting it up for a big sell-off on Friday morning—particularly if the company’s outlook for 2026 disappoints.
Jan 22, 2026

True Value

Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense

By Anita Ramaswamy

Intel’s stock price has more than doubled in the past five months, since President Donald Trump announced the U.S. government would buy a 10% stake in the ailing chip manufacturer, followed by similar investments from SoftBank and Nvidia. Investors are betting the new capital, coupled with a surge in AI demand, will help resuscitate the company.

Those expectations will collide with reality when Intel reports fourth-quarter earnings late this afternoon, either making or breaking the rally. Intel bears say the stock has moved way too high, setting it up for a big sell-off on Friday morning—particularly if the company’s outlook for 2026 disappoints.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Intel’s stock valuation now exceeds TSMC’s
  • Intel’s revenue has declined, missing the AI chip boom that boosted TSMC.
  • Analysts question Intel’s high valuation given execution risks and PC reliance.

Nine Tech IPO Contenders to Watch This Year

By Valida Pau

Thinking Machines Exodus Tests Investor Appetite for a $50 Billion Valuation

By Erin Woo and Stephanie Palazzolo

By Catherine Perloff and Sri Muppidi


Exclusive

By Erin Woo

optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Prompt of the Week 🧠</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong>Customer Support → Turn messy tickets into clear SOPs.</strong></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>If you manage support (or ops), this prompt helps you turn </span><em>real customer issues</em><span> into repeatable processes your team can follow.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em><strong>Prompt:</strong></em></p><pre style="position: relative;background: rgb(238,238,238);padding: 16px;margin: 32px 0;border-radius: 8px;box-sizing: border-box;"><code style="white-space: pre-wrap;font-size: 16px;line-height: 20px;font-weight: 500;"><span>You are an Operations Lead building internal SOPs from customer support tickets.

Your job: transform the ticket thread below into a clear, repeatable SOP that any new team member can follow.

</span><strong>Output format (exact):</strong><span>
- SOP Title (max 8 words)
- When to use this SOP (1 sentence)
- Goal (1 sentence)
- Required info to collect (bullet list)
- Step-by-step process (numbered steps)
- Decision tree (If/Then bullets for the 3 most common branches)
- Copy-paste responses (3 templates: “first reply”, “need more info”, “resolved”)
- Escalation rules (when to escalate + to who)
- SOP owner + review cadence (suggest a role + how often to review)

</span><strong>Constraints:</strong><span>
- Keep it practical, short sentences, no fluff
- Assume the reader is new to the company
- Highlight any missing info as “⚠️ Missing”

Ticket thread (paste everything):
[PASTE TICKET / EMAIL THREAD HERE]

</span><strong>Company context (optional):</strong><span>
- Product: [what you sell]
- Tools: [Zendesk/Intercom/Slack/etc.
- Refund policy: [paste if relevant]</span></code></pre><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong>Where to use it:</strong><br><span>Support teams, ops teams, founders handling support themselves, onboarding new reps, building a knowledge base fast.</span></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>🚨 Need help with AI? item.title: What the Team Behind Cursor Knows About the Future of Code
item.description:
Cursor team members share their thoughts on building software with AI and why model selection beats prompting tricks  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Source Code

What the Team Behind Cursor Knows About the Future of Code

Cursor team members share their thoughts on building software with AI and why model selection beats prompting tricks

by Katie Parrott

Happening now: We’re hosting Vibe Code Camp with the world’s best experts pushing the limits of what’s possible. Watch live now until 6 p.m. ET, and catch the recordings. Also: This article is based on a sponsored event. Cursor provided $100 in credits to attendees and made this camp possible.—Kate Lee

A few minutes into Every’s first Cursor Camp, Cursor developer education lead Lee Robinson made a bold declaration: “The IDE is kind of dead.”

IIDE stands for “integrated development environment”—basically Microsoft Word, but for code. It’s where programmers type, organize files, and run programs, and for decades, it has been the center of a programmer’s world.

Now, that model is breaking down. The center of gravity has shifted from typing code by hand in an IDE such as Visual Studio Code to managing AI agents that write it for you with a tool such as Cursor.

In this session, Lee and Samantha Whitmore, a software engineer at Cursor, walked us through how they work in a post-IDE world. What follows are the workflows, model-selection strategies, and honest limitations they shared—plus where this leaves you if you’re trying to figure out what the future of code looks like.

Key takeaways

  1. The agent is becoming the core. Writing and editing code by hand is shrinking as a percentage of the work. Developers are now spending more time telling AI agents what to build and reviewing their output.
  2. Cloud and local agents are merging. You’ll soon be able to start an agent on your computer, hand it off to remote servers when you close your laptop, and pick it back up later—no context lost.
  3. Model choice matters more than prompting tricks. Prompting gimmicks like, “I’ll pay you $1,000,” which some AI users swore could make AI provide a better output, don’t work anymore. You need to choose the right model for the job—say, one for brainstorming, another for deep bug-hunting.
  4. Agents can run for weeks. Cursor’s research team built a working web browser from scratch using AI agents that ran for days, producing 3 million lines of code. It cost $80,000 in tokens (the units AI companies use to measure and charge for usage). It’s a research project that’s not available for public use—for now. But it shows where things are heading.

Move fast, don’t break things

Most AI coding tools don’t know which line of code will actually break your system. Try Augment Code, which understands your entire codebase, including the repos, languages, and dependencies that actually runs your business, and use their playbook to learn more about their framework, checklists, and assessments. Ship 30% faster with 40% shorter merge times.

Playbook at augmentcode.com
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

What ‘the death of the IDE’ means

Cursor looks like a traditional coding tool on the surface. There are files on the left, code in the middle, and now an AI chat panel on the side, where you can ask the agent to do things.


For many Cursor users, that chat panel has become the main event. Some don’t even look at the code output much—they work entirely in conversation with the AI, only reviewing the final result.

According to Lee, developers used to interact with Cursor primarily by writing code by hand and using an autocomplete function, where the AI suggests the next line of code as you type, similar to predictive text on your phone. But Lee says recent Cursor’s usage data tells a different story: More and more developers are working inside the agent interface. He said that writing code by hand may comprise as little as 10 percent of the time for some developers.

This is why he believes that easier text editing—for which Cursor and tools like it were originally built—is less important than the coding agent—which writes and edits code—and the ability to review the agent’s output and track changes.

And with new tools and integrations being built every day (like Every’s compound engineering plugin), it seems likely the old ways of AI-enabled coding will slip farther down the ranking.

A browser built from scratch by AI (for $80,000)

When you use an AI coding tool, you’re really using two things: the model (the AI brain that generates code) and the scaffolding known as the harness around it (the infrastructure that lets that brain do things—run commands, edit files, handle errors, and manage context). The model comes from OpenAI or Anthropic. The harness is what Cursor builds.

The same model can perform very differently depending on its harness. A well-tuned harness knows how to feed the model the right context, when to truncate long outputs, how to recover from errors, and how to keep the AI on track during long tasks.

To stress-test what a well-tuned harness could do, Cursor’s team built a custom research harness around GPT 5.2 and set it loose on an absurd task: building a fully functional web browser from scratch. AI produced 3 million lines of code across thousands of files, generated over weeks of continuous running, at a cost of around $80,000 in tokens. The browser that resulted could render web pages, handle Flexbox (a layout system for web design), display images, and run scripts.

At $80,000, this is a hefty research project, not something your average solo developer could try on a Tuesday afternoon. But a year ago, the same task would have been impossible at any price. If costs continue to come down, “Let the agent run for a week on something ambitious” might feel less like a stunt in time.

How a Cursor coder uses Cursor

Cursor’s team uses Cursor to build Cursor. Their workflows are both a window into power-user techniques and a preview of where the tool is headed because the features they find themselves wanting tend to become the features they build.

Sam showed how she’s building features for Cursor’s cloud agents product, including the ability to move an agent from your local computer to the cloud—in other words, a remote server—and back.

Right now, if you start an AI agent on your laptop and then close it for lunch, the agent stops. Sam’s project would let you hand the agent off to run in the cloud, check on its progress from your phone, and have it back your computer when you’re ready.

Planning comes first

Before Sam writes any code, she spends serious time in “plan mode,” a Cursor feature where you talk to the AI about what you want to build before it starts building. For complex projects, she’ll share designs and screenshots, and have a long conversation to create a detailed plan.

The more detailed your upfront plan, the less the AI wanders off into expensive tangents. “Plan mode“—whether in Cursor, Claude Code, or any other tool—has become gospel among top AI-powered coders.

For large plans, Sam uses multiple agents working in parallel, manually breaking the work into pieces. For small-to-medium plans, she might use one or two agents. For simple bug fixes, she sometimes skips planning entirely.

Model selection is based on vibes

Sam has developed what she calls “personal vibe assessments” for different AI models, rough heuristics for when to use which model:

  1. Claude Opus: This is Sam’s brainstorming buddy. It’s good at connecting dots and helping when something is poorly specified, plus it can zoom out and correct itself.
  2. GPT 5.2 Codex High: Sam says Codex has “robotic energy.” It takes you at your exact word. It’s also incredibly thorough for bug-finding, but it can get fixated on one approach instead of stepping back to try something different.

Sometimes she uses both at once, running the same task through multiple models in parallel and comparing the results. Cursor has a feature called “best of n” that lets you run up to eight models simultaneously on the same problem. Sometimes, if a bug is tricky to fix, Sam will have Codex and Opus go head-to-head to see which model’s approach comes out on top.

When multiple models return different answers, she interviews them. She’ll ask one model to justify its approach, then share that reasoning with another model and ask what it thinks. It’s a bit manual, but it helps her understand the problem deeply before deciding what to do.

Review is part of the workflow

Cursor has built-in review tools. There’s a “find issues” button that kicks off another agent to review the code from a fresh perspective. They also have a tool called Bugbot that automatically reviews GitHub pull requests (the drafts developers submit before code goes live) and flags likely bugs.

Sam said Cursor has an internal policy: Don’t merge code until you’ve addressed all Bugbot comments.

Retrieval over compression

Sam has shifted her thinking in one more way recently. She used to think you needed to compress conversations into summaries for AI to remember past work. Now she prefers a “retrieval first” approach: Instead of summaries, she gives the AI pointers to past conversations and plan documents and lets it explore them as needed.

“The agents have gotten so good at exploring pointers to files,” she said.

Q&A highlights

Q: Where is the early access channel for new features?

In Cursor settings under “beta,” you can choose between stable, early access, and nightly releases. Lee recommended early access for people who want to try new features without dealing with frequent bugs or crashes.

Q: How does Cursor handle context as agents run longer?

Cursor now uses a “pointer” system. Instead of stuffing the AI’s memory with full documents, it gives the agent pointers to files and lets it explore them as needed. This prevents the AI from getting confused by too much information at once.

“The models are smart enough now to go explore it and use file read tools and grep tools to explore this context as it needs,” Sam said. Grep refers to a command to search for and find matching text patterns in files.

Q: Do prompting tricks like “I’ll pay you $1,000” still work?

No. The Cursor team said steering the model with rewards or threats has become less important than managing context pollution (preventing the AI from being overwhelmed with irrelevant information). The models are already well-trained for coding tasks—the trick is staying out of their way.

Q: I do simple websites from Figma designs. I can’t get agents to match the design faster than doing it myself.

Sam said this is tricky for companies like Cursor. The Figma integration is built by Figma, not the AI companies, so the models haven’t been trained on how to use it. You’ll likely need to experiment more with your prompts to get good results.

For straightforward design-to-code translation—taking a static design and turning it into working code, the bread and butter of many web developers—AI tools still don’t reliably beat human speed. The gains seem concentrated in more complex, multi-step tasks where the AI can run longer and handle more scope.

Questions to ask before switching

As someone without a software engineering background but who vibe codes frequently, here’s what I came away from this camp thinking: Cursor’s vision is compelling—agents that run for weeks, seamlessly move between your laptop and the cloud, and handle projects that would take human developers months. But the gap between the demo and daily reality is worth examining.

A few things stood out:

The cost barrier is real—for now. Sam admitted she “literally never looks at” token usage, relying on the $200-per-month unlimited plan. For people doing simpler tasks or with smaller budgets, the calculus might be different.

Design translation remains hard. The question about Figma-to-code workflows didn’t get a satisfying answer. If you’re a web developer doing straightforward implementation work, these tools may not save you time yet.

Model selection is becoming its own expertise. Knowing when to use Opus versus Codex, run multiple models in parallel, and interview the AI about its choices, among other things, is emerging as its own skill set.

That shift has implications beyond professional developers. If agents can build browsers from scratch, what else becomes possible for people who’ve never written a line of code?

The answer, based on what I saw: complex, multi-step projects where you can describe what you want and review what you get. The simpler the task—the more it’s about matching a specific design or writing a single function—the less these tools help.

Whether the IDE is “dead” or evolving, one thing is clear: The teams building these tools have huge amounts of influence on the direction AI-powered coding is headed. It’s good to know what they’re building—and to test their claims against your own experience.

Want more hands-on training with AI tools? Join us for our next camp. Subscribe to Every and keep an eye on your inbox.

Katie Parrott is a staff writer and AI editorial lead at Every. You can read more of her work in her newsletter.

To read more essays like this, subscribe to Every, and follow us on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

We build AI tools for readers like you. Write brilliantly with Spiral. Organize files automatically with Sparkle. Deliver yourself from email with Cora. Dictate effortlessly with Monologue.

We also do AI training, adoption, and innovation for companies. Work with us to bring AI into your organization.

Get paid for sharing Every with your friends. Join our referral program.

Help us scale the only subscription you need to stay at the edge of AI. Explore open roles at Every.

AI Frontiers on TechCrunch
January 22, 2026
YouTube will soon let creators make Shorts with their own AI likeness
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/youtube-will-soon-let-creators-make-shorts-with-their-own-ai-likeness/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • YouTube will enable creators to use AI-generated versions of their own likeness in Shorts, alongside tools for creating games and experimenting with music via text prompts.
  • • The platform is enhancing AI tools, such as AI stickers and auto-dubbing, while also providing creators with controls to manage and protect their likeness in AI-generated content.
  • • To combat low-quality AI content, YouTube is expanding its systems to reduce spam, clickbait, and repetitive content, ensuring a high-quality viewing experience.
Not to be outdone by OpenAI, Apple is reportedly developing an AI wearable
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/not-to-be-outdone-by-openai-apple-is-reportedly-developing-an-ai-wearable/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Apple is rumored to be working on an AI wearable pin featuring two cameras, three microphones, a speaker, and a physical button. The device is described as a sleek, aluminum-and-glass disc, slightly thicker than an AirTag.
  • • The pin, expected to launch by 2027 with 20 million units, aims to compete with OpenAI’s anticipated AI hardware, potentially a pair of earbuds, signaling growing competition in the AI hardware market.
  • • Similar devices, like Humane AI’s wearable pin, struggled to gain traction, raising questions about consumer demand for AI wearables.
Irony alert: Hallucinated citations found in papers from NeurIPS, the prestigious AI conference
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/irony-alert-hallucinated-citations-found-in-papers-from-neurips-the-prestigious-ai-conference/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • GPTZero analyzed 4,841 papers from the NeurIPS conference and identified 100 fake citations across 51 papers, highlighting how AI tools like LLMs can introduce errors even in high-stakes academic research.
  • • While the fake citations represent a small fraction of the total, their presence raises concerns about the integrity of scholarly publishing and the challenges of peer review under the pressure of massive submission volumes.
  • • The findings underscore a broader issue: if leading AI researchers struggle to verify AI-generated outputs, it raises questions about the reliability of AI usage in other fields.
Todoist’s app now lets you add tasks to your to-do list by speaking to its AI
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/todoists-app-now-lets-you-add-tasks-to-your-to-do-list-by-speaking-to-its-ai/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Todoist Ramble leverages AI and large language models to convert natural speech into organized tasks, capturing details like deadlines, priorities, and assignees in real time.
  • • Built on Google’s Gemini 2.5 Flash Live model via Vertex AI, the feature ensures secure processing with SOC2 Type II certification and does not store audio for AI training.
  • • Available in 38 languages across iOS, Android, desktop, and web, Ramble offers limited sessions for free users and unlimited access for Pro and Business plans, driving higher user upgrades during beta testing.
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/22/former-google-trio-is-building-an-interactive-ai-powered-learning-app-for-kids/
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

  • • This shift comes as Apple faces mounting competition from AI leaders like OpenAI and their hardware ambitions, led by former Apple designer Jony Ive.
  • • After testing various AI technologies, Apple selected Google’s Gemini as its AI partner, signaling a strategic push to catch up in the competitive AI landscape.

item.title: 🫳🏼 A crawling, detachable robot hand
item.description:
PLUS: Zipline comes to more cities  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

January 22nd, 2026   |   Read Online

Read Online | Sign Up | Advertise

Good morning, TT. EPFL roboticists just built a robotic hand that can detach itself and crawl away from its arm — basically “Thing” from The Addams Family, but engineered in Switzerland.

With freakishly flexible, reversible fingers, it can grip from either side — and even juggle extra tasks with a sixth digit. Is this the next big leap in real-world dexterity?

 

In today’s robotics rundown:

  • Robotic hand detaches and crawls on its own

  • Zipline soars to $7.6B as it targets Houston, Phoenix

  • Sailbots take on Category 5 hurricanes

  • Serve Robotics moves into hospital bots

  • Quick hits on other robotics news

LATEST DEVELOPMENTS

EPFL

✌🏼 Robotic hand detaches and crawls on its own

Image source: EPFL

The Rundown: Researchers at Switzerland’s EPFL just built a robotic hand that can detach from its arm, scuttle across a surface, and grab objects beyond the reach of conventional manipulators.

The details:

  • The EPFL team built this robotic hand from 3D printable parts, with the ability to detach from its arm, crawl, grab objects, and reattach itself.

  • The reversible design lets any finger combination form opposing thumb-like pairs, enabling grasping from either side without repositioning.

  • Each finger bends in both directions with more than twice the range of motion of a human hand, optimized via genetic algorithms for grasping and locomotion.

  • With five fingers, it replicates most human grasps; add a sixth finger, and it can tackle two-handed tasks singlehandedly, like unscrewing a large bottle cap.

Why it matters: This hand challenges a core assumption in robotics — that manipulators must stay bolted to their arms. By treating it as an autonomous agent that can deploy, complete a task, and return, EPFL’s design hints at a future where robotic limbs become interchangeable tools rather than fixed appendages.

ZIPLINE

🌯 Zipline soars to $7.6B as it targets Houston, Phoenix

Image source: Zipline

The Rundown: Zipline just raised more than $600M to fuel a fresh U.S. push that will launch its autonomous drone delivery in Houston and Phoenix in early 2026 and support expansion into at least four states.

The details:

  • Zipline’s valuation has nearly tripled in under three years, leaping from $2.75B in mid-2021 to $7.6B today.

  • Zipline says it has surpassed 2M commercial deliveries globally, with its drones flying more than 125M autonomous miles and delivering over 20M items.

  • The company began operations in 2016, delivering blood by drone in Rwanda, and has spent the past decade building a vertically integrated logistics stack.

  • Its Platform 2 drones, tailored for suburban home delivery, can carry up to 8 lb. within a 10‑mile radius, while the Platform 1 handles 120‑mile round trips.

Why it matters: Zipline says its newest U.S. sites can ramp to 100 deliveries a day in just two days, turning what used to be slow, geofenced pilots into something that starts to look like real infrastructure. Rivals Amazon Prime Air and Walmart’s drone partners Wing and DroneUp are pushing hard too — the drone wars are officially on.

CLIMATE ROBOTICS

🌊 Sailbots take on Category 5 hurricanes

Image source: Oshen

The Rundown: Bootstrapped UK startup Oshen has built swarms of low-cost autonomous “C-Star” robots that recently became the first ocean bots to survive and collect data from inside a Category 5 hurricane, its founder told Techcrunch.

The details:

  • Oshen builds autonomous micro-robots that can survive up to 100 days at sea and are cheap enough to deploy in swarms for ocean data collection.

  • Founder Anahita Laverack launched the company in 2022 after realizing how little real-time ocean data exists for weather and climate modeling.

  • OAA commissioned Oshen to deploy C-Stars near the U.S. Virgin Islands for Hurricane Humberto; three of five bots rode out the full Category 5 storm.

  • Oshen, now based in Plymouth (England’s marine tech hub), is signing new government and defense contracts, including with the UK government.

Why it matters: Oshen’s C-Star swarms show how micro-robots could plug a critical gap in hurricane and climate models by streaming real-time data from places that are tough to reach, intensifying competition with larger uncrewed fleets like Saildrone’s USVs already collecting high-res storm data for NOAA and navies worldwide.

SERVE ROBOTICS

🏥 Serve Robotics moves into hospital bots

Image source: Serve Robotics

The Rundown: Serve Robotics is pushing beyond burrito runs into the far messier world of hospital logistics, agreeing to buy Austin-based Diligent Robotics in an all-stock deal valuing the startup at about $29M.

The details:

  • The deal extends Serve from sidewalk delivery to hospital logistics, but CEO Ali Kashani frames it as a natural expansion of the same autonomy stack.

  • Diligent’s Moxi robots are already one of the largest deployed hospital service fleets in the U.S., with roughly 100 robots across more than 25 hospitals.

  • Serve plans to keep Diligent operating independently while sharing software, autonomy tools, and data so that “every robot learns from every robot.”

  • Serve’s sidewalk fleet, which runs on both DoorDash and Uber Eats networks, scaled from 100 to more than 2K robots over the past year.

Why it matters: This deal turns Serve from a niche food-delivery player into one of the first companies running a shared autonomy stack across both public sidewalks and hospital corridors — a real-world stress test for “physical AI,” the bet that one platform can learn to navigate any human-occupied space and port those lessons everywhere.

QUICK HITS

📰 Everything else in robotics today

1X’s VP of AI, Eric Jang, who helped scale 1X from a small Norway-based startup to a global humanoid giant, announced on X that he is leaving the company.

Chinese robotics firm UBTech signed a deal to supply its Walker S2 humanoids to Airbus for aviation manufacturing, which sent UBTech’s shares surging.

UBTech says its Walker S2 humanoids are now autonomously performing assembly and material-handling tasks inside a Chinese wind turbine factory.

XPeng’s CEO, He Xiaopeng, said their automotive-grade ET1 humanoid has rolled off the production line, with the first mass-produced test units focused on reliability.

Hyundai’s Boston Dynamics hired Milan Kovac, Tesla’s former senior VP and head of the Optimus humanoid program, as a group adviser and outside director.

DEEP Robotics launched an AI-powered firefighting system that uses coordinated robot dogs and other specialized robots to handle high-risk firefighting missions.

Microsoft unveiled Rho-alpha, a robotics AI that converts everyday language into robot actions by combining vision and touch for more reliable real-world manipulation.

Boston Dynamics updated its Spot platform and Orbit software to version 5.1 and introduced the Spot Cam 2 sensor head, sharpening its inspection capabilities.

Zhejiang University researchers built FlexiRay, a soft robotic gripper that uses an internal camera and mirror system to “see” around corners.

COMMUNITY

🎓 Highlights: News, Guides & Events

  • Read our last AI newsletter: Anthropic writes Claude's Constitution

  • Read our last Tech newsletter: Biotech’s big three (and they’re wild)

  • Read our last Robotics newsletter: 1X now has a world model

  • Today’s AI tool guide: Make Claude an expert at anything with Skills repo

  • RSVP to next workshop @ 4PM EST Thursday: AI Foundations Bootcamp pt.3

That's it for today!

Before you go we'd love to know what you thought of today's newsletter to help us improve The Rundown experience for you.

🤖🤖🤖🤖🤖 Nailed it

🤖🤖🤖 Average

🤖 Fail

See you soon,

Rowan, Joey, Zach, Shubham, and Jennifer — The Rundown’s editorial team

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 22, 2026
Your brain on ChatGPT: Accumulation of cognitive debt when using an AI assistant
• Article: https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46712678
• Score: 383
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A study compared essay writing across three groups: AI-powered Large Language Models (LLMs), Search Engine users, and Brain-only (no tools). Results showed LLM users had the weakest brain connectivity and lowest cognitive engagement, while Brain-only participants demonstrated the strongest neural activity.
  • • LLM reliance led to reduced cognitive ownership and long-term underperformance in neural, linguistic, and behavioral metrics. Participants transitioning from LLMs to Brain-only writing struggled with cognitive engagement, raising concerns about AI's educational impact.
  • • Findings highlight the trade-offs between immediate convenience offered by LLMs and potential cognitive costs, emphasizing the need for further research into AI's role in learning.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • • **Cognitive Impact of AI Usage**: Many commenters discussed how relying on AI, particularly for tasks like coding or essay writing, can lead to cognitive atrophy, reduced engagement, and diminished understanding of the underlying material. However, others noted that AI can be a valuable tool when used correctly, such as for explaining concepts or accelerating productivity.
  • • **Historical Comparisons**: A recurring theme was comparing AI to past technological advancements (e.g., writing, calculators, GPS). Commenters debated whether these tools fundamentally shifted or diminished human cognitive abilities and whether similar concerns about AI are justified.
  • • **AI as a Tool vs. Replacement**: Several commenters highlighted the distinction between using AI as an assistive tool versus allowing it to take over tasks entirely. Many advocated for using AI to augment human work rather than replace critical thinking or hands-on learning.
  • • **Educational and Long-Term Implications**: Concerns were raised about how reliance on AI might affect learning, skill development, and problem-solving over time. Commenters discussed the potential for AI to disrupt traditional education and training pipelines, particularly in fields like programming.
  • • **Personal Experiences with AI**: Commenters shared anecdotes about their own experiences with AI tools, ranging from increased productivity and overcoming ADHD-related challenges to feeling disengaged or frustrated when relying too heavily on AI.
  • 2. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreements**:
  • • Many agreed that over-reliance on AI can lead to skill atrophy and reduced cognitive engagement.
  • • There was broad consensus that AI tools are most effective when used as aids for learning or productivity rather than as replacements for human effort.
  • • Several commenters supported the idea that AI should be used to focus on higher-level tasks while offloading repetitive or tedious work.
  • • **Disagreements**:
  • • Some commenters believed that AI is fundamentally different from past tools like calculators or writing because it can take over entire cognitive processes, while others argued that such concerns mirror historical fears about new technologies.
  • • There was debate about whether the downsides of AI use outweigh its benefits, with some emphasizing the risks of cognitive decline and others highlighting its potential for augmenting human capabilities.
  • • A few commenters dismissed the study as flawed or unscientific, while others found its findings credible and aligned with their own observations.
  • 3. **Unique Insights and Notable Contributions**:
  • • Several commenters noted the importance of actively engaging with AI tools (e.g., asking questions, fact-checking) to mitigate cognitive atrophy and enhance learning.
  • • A comparison was made between managing AI and managing human subordinates, suggesting that principles of good management could inform effective AI use.
  • • Some highlighted the potential for AI to create a divide between those who rely heavily on it and those who retain traditional problem-solving skills, potentially leading to a "talent crunch" in certain fields.
  • • A few commenters proposed solutions to mitigate AI's negative effects, such as using it to create personalized learning experiences or imposing limits on its accessibility.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion was mixed, with a balance of cautious optimism and concern. While many commenters acknowledged the productivity and learning benefits of AI, there was significant apprehension about its long-term cognitive and societal impacts. The tone ranged from reflective and analytical to skeptical and critical, with occasional humor and sarcasm.
  • 5. **Key Takeaways**:
  • • AI tools can enhance productivity and learning but require careful, intentional use to avoid negative cognitive effects.
  • • Historical parallels suggest that concerns about AI may be part of a broader pattern of initial resistance to new technologies, though AI's unique capabilities raise distinct challenges.
  • • The long-term implications of AI reliance on education, skill development, and societal structures remain uncertain and warrant further research and consideration.
How AI destroys institutions
• Article: https://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/publications/how-ai-destroys-institutions/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46705606
• Score: 298
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Civic institutions like the rule of law, universities, and a free press rely on transparency, cooperation, and accountability to adapt and sustain democratic life, empowering individuals to challenge norms and foster stability.
  • • Current AI systems undermine these foundational principles by eroding expertise, disrupting decision-making processes, and isolating individuals, making them incompatible with the evolution and legitimacy of civic institutions.
  • • The essay argues that AI’s design and functionality pose a severe threat to the survival of vital democratic structures, calling for urgent recognition of this existential risk.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • • The role of AI in accelerating societal changes and its impact on institutions like universities, the press, and the rule of law.
  • • The debate over whether AI is the root cause of institutional decline or merely an accelerant of pre-existing issues.
  • • Concerns about AI eroding expertise, critical thinking, and interpersonal connections.
  • • Broader societal factors contributing to the erosion of trust in institutions, such as capitalism, corruption, and social media.
  • • The potential for AI to democratize access to knowledge and tools, but also the risks of misinformation and accountability gaps.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • • Many commenters agree that AI is amplifying existing problems rather than creating them from scratch.
  • • There is consensus that institutions were already facing challenges, such as declining trust, inefficiency, and corruption, before the rise of AI.
  • • AI’s ability to enhance productivity and accessibility is acknowledged, but it comes with the caveat of needing careful management.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • • Some commenters argue that AI should be blamed for accelerating institutional decline, likening it to "throwing gas on a fire," while others believe the root causes lie elsewhere, such as in capitalism or systemic failures.
  • • Diverging views on whether AI is fundamentally destructive or can be harnessed positively to complement institutions.
  • • Opinions differ on whether institutions like universities and the press are still essential or have become outdated and self-serving.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters highlight that institutional fragility predates AI and is tied to broader societal trends, such as the commodification of education and the influence of profit-driven motives.
  • • A commenter draws parallels between AI and previous technological disruptions, such as the internet and YouTube, which restructured traditional industries without completely destroying them.
  • • Another perspective emphasizes the potential for AI to exacerbate societal inequalities by empowering those who can use it effectively while disadvantaging others.
  • 5. **Sentiment of the Discussion**:
  • • The overall sentiment is mixed, with a blend of skepticism, concern, and cautious optimism.
  • • Many commenters express frustration with existing institutions and their inability to adapt, but there is also apprehension about AI’s potential to destabilize society further.
  • • Some comments reflect a sense of inevitability about AI-driven changes, while others call for proactive regulation and accountability.
  • 6. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • The analogy of AI as a "wrecking ball" or "accelerant" was frequently used to describe its impact on fragile systems.
  • • Commenters debated the role of institutional trust, with some arguing that institutions must earn trust by improving lives, while others believe trust has eroded due to systemic corruption.
  • • The discussion touched on the dual nature of AI: as a tool for empowerment and democratization, but also as a potential source of harm if misused.
  • 7. **Concluding Observations**:
  • • The discussion reflects deep concerns about the interplay between AI and societal structures, with no clear consensus on how to address the challenges.
  • • While some commenters see AI as a tool for progress, others view it as a threat to the foundational principles of democratic life.
  • • The debate underscores the need for thoughtful regulation, transparency, and public accountability in the deployment of AI technologies.
eBay explicitly bans AI "buy for me" agents in user agreement update
• Article: https://www.valueaddedresource.net/ebay-bans-ai-agents-updates-arbitration-user-agreement-feb-2026/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46711574
• Score: 209
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • eBay explicitly prohibits AI-driven "buy for me" agents and large language model (LLM) bots from interacting with its platform without prior permission, aiming to prevent unauthorized automated transactions and data scraping.
  • • Arbitration updates include clarified class action waivers, an opt-out process, and a revised physical address for dispute notices, enhancing transparency in dispute resolution.
  • • The move aligns with broader industry concerns, potentially responding to Amazon's controversial AI-powered commerce experiments, highlighting growing scrutiny around AI's role in e-commerce.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Theme**: The discussion centers on eBay's ban on AI-powered "buy-for-me" bots, with participants debating the rationale, implications, and fairness of the decision.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • • **eBay's Motivation**:
  • • Several commenters argue that the ban is primarily about protecting eBay's business model, particularly its reliance on impulse buying, ad revenue, and user engagement ("wandering attention").
  • • Others suggest the ban is aimed at avoiding potential liabilities, such as AI errors leading to incorrect purchases, returns, or scams.
  • • Some see it as a move to prevent AI from commoditizing eBay into a backend database, reducing its role in the user experience.
  • • **Fairness and Double Standards**:
  • • Many express frustration that eBay allows sniping bots (which bid at the last moment in auctions) but bans "buy-for-me" bots, viewing this as inconsistent.
  • • Some commenters note that sniping bots benefit eBay by keeping users engaged on the platform, whereas "buy-for-me" bots bypass user interaction and reduce ad exposure.
  • • **User Experience and AI Utility**:
  • • Several commenters highlight the potential usefulness of AI agents for tasks like monitoring listings, identifying deals, and automating purchases, particularly for niche or time-sensitive needs.
  • • Concerns are raised about the challenges of teaching AI to accurately interpret user preferences and avoid errors.
  • • Some suggest that eBay's poor user experience, including excessive notifications and spam, pushes users toward automating their interactions via AI.
  • • **Scalability and Abuse**:
  • • Participants discuss the potential for AI-driven automation to be abused at scale, such as by drop shippers or arbitrageurs who scrape listings and relist them for profit, creating additional load on platforms.
  • • Commenters also note that such automation could lead to increased returns, cancellations, and fraud, further straining eBay's infrastructure.
  • • **Enforcement Challenges**:
  • • Many are skeptical about eBay's ability to enforce the ban, given the sophistication of bots and the difficulty of distinguishing them from human users.
  • • Others argue that the ban is more about creating a policy framework to address issues as they arise rather than immediate, proactive enforcement.
  • 3. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Some commenters suggest that eBay could monetize AI interactions by licensing API access or offering official AI tools, similar to how other companies are adapting to AI's impact.
  • • There is a broader reflection on how AI could disrupt marketplaces by leveling the playing field against existing automation (e.g., sniping bots, scalpers).
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment is mixed, with significant skepticism toward eBay's motives and policies. While some acknowledge the potential risks of AI automation, many view the ban as self-serving and indicative of broader issues with eBay's business practices and user experience.
  • 5. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • A few commenters highlight practical use cases for AI in e-commerce, such as assisting blind users or automating complex purchase decisions.
  • • Others share personal experiences with eBay, illustrating frustrations with fees, fraud, and the platform's declining usability.
  • 6. **Broader Implications**:
  • • The discussion reflects a larger tension between the benefits of AI-driven automation for users and the challenges it poses for businesses reliant on traditional engagement models.
  • • Commenters note parallels with other industries adapting to AI, suggesting that eBay's move is part of a broader trend of companies seeking to protect their revenue streams in the face of technological disruption.
Letting Claude play text adventures
• Article: https://borretti.me/article/letting-claude-play-text-adventures
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46652173
• Score: 141
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • An AI hackathon participant experimented with combining cognitive architecture principles, like those from Soar and ACT-R, with large language models (LLMs) to improve their performance in long-horizon tasks, using text adventure games as a testing ground.
  • • The project highlighted challenges such as token limitations and memory management in LLMs, leading to the development of experimental harnesses, including semantic memory and task-specific tools, to enhance efficiency and gameplay navigation.
  • • Future plans include implementing domain-specific memories, automatic and manual geography mapping, and episodic memory to refine LLMs' ability to handle complex, structured environments more effectively.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around using large language models (LLMs), particularly Claude, to play text adventure games, with a focus on memory management, reasoning capabilities, and experimental frameworks.
  • 2. **Themes**:
  • • **Training Data and Performance**: Several commenters speculate on whether Claude's training data includes walkthroughs or transcripts of games like Anchorhead. Opinions vary on whether this would impact its ability to solve puzzles effectively.
  • • **Memory and Context Management**: There is significant discussion on how LLMs handle memory, with suggestions for structured memory tools, periodic summaries, and context compaction to improve performance in long-running sessions.
  • • **Symbolic AI and Hybrid Approaches**: Some commenters debate the relevance of symbolic AI in modern systems, suggesting it could serve as scaffolding for LLMs to handle causality and constraints better.
  • • **Applications and Experiments**: Commenters share their experiments, such as using Claude to play MUDs, Z-Machine games, and Dwarf Fortress clones, highlighting its potential for testing interactive fiction and software development.
  • • **Challenges with LLMs**: Observations include inefficiencies in maze-solving, high token costs for long sessions, and the inability of LLMs to manage their own memory optimally.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is general agreement that LLMs struggle with memory management and could benefit from external tools or structured frameworks.
  • • Some commenters are skeptical about the performance of LLMs in solving puzzles or playing games, especially if the games are well-known and potentially included in training data.
  • • Others highlight promising use cases for LLMs, such as testing game development or enhancing text adventure experiences.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment is mixed. Many commenters express enthusiasm for the potential of LLMs in gaming and testing applications, while others are critical of their current limitations, such as inefficiencies and lack of contextual awareness.
  • 5. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters propose innovative approaches to improve LLM performance, such as combining structured memory tools with symbolic AI, externalizing geometry in mazes, and using file-based memory types to mimic human-like recall.
  • • The idea of using LLMs for CI/CD testing in interactive fiction development is highlighted as a novel application.
  • • The concept of treating memory as structured game objects with explicit states and affordances is proposed as a way to enhance reasoning and coherence.
  • 6. **Overall Summary**:
  • • The discussion showcases both the potential and limitations of LLMs in playing text adventure games. While there is excitement about experimental frameworks and applications, commenters emphasize the need for better memory management and structured approaches to improve reasoning and gameplay capabilities. Hybrid approaches combining symbolic AI and LLMs are suggested as a promising direction for addressing current challenges.
Comic-Con Bans AI Art After Artist Pushback
• Article: https://www.404media.co/comic-con-bans-ai-art-after-artist-pushback/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46705952
• Score: 124
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • San Diego Comic-Con reversed its AI-friendly policy for its art show after an artist-led protest, now banning all AI-generated content to protect the integrity of creative work.
  • • Artists like Karla Ortiz highlighted how generative AI undermines livelihoods by replacing traditional creative processes, with examples from Marvel and Coca-Cola showcasing the growing industry reliance on AI.
  • • Despite the policy change, concerns persist as AI-generated art continues to appear at conventions, raising ethical debates about its exploitation of original artworks without credit or compensation.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • • The ethics and legitimacy of AI-generated art, particularly in creative spaces like conventions.
  • • The evolving definition of art and the boundaries between traditional, digital, and AI-assisted creation.
  • • Concerns about authenticity, craftsmanship, and the impact of AI on artistic livelihoods.
  • • The role of tools and technology in the creative process, including comparisons to past innovations like Photoshop and photography.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • • Many commenters argue that AI-generated art lacks the moral and creative authenticity valued by traditional artists, especially when training data involves unconsented use of existing works.
  • • There is disagreement over whether AI tools are simply another medium for creativity or if they undermine the artistic process by removing human skill and effort.
  • • Some contributors highlight historical parallels, such as debates around digital art and the use of assistants in traditional art, suggesting that resistance to new technologies is not new.
  • • Others propose a spectrum of AI involvement in art, ranging from minor assistance to fully AI-generated works, with the degree of human engagement influencing perceptions of value and authenticity.
  • • Concerns about false accusations of AI use and the potential for AI-generated content to dominate spaces like conventions were also raised.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is broad agreement that generative AI raises ethical concerns, particularly around copyright and training data. However, views differ on whether AI art can or should be considered "real art.
  • • Some commenters believe AI tools could be valuable for enhancing creativity or automating repetitive tasks, while others feel they fundamentally devalue artistic work.
  • • Disagreement exists over whether AI art will eventually be accepted as part of the artistic landscape, with some predicting it will follow the trajectory of past technological shifts and others expressing skepticism about its long-term viability in creative fields.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment is mixed but leans toward skepticism and concern about the implications of AI art on creativity, ethics, and artistic livelihoods. While some commenters are optimistic about AI's potential as a tool, many express fears about its impact on authenticity and the art community.
  • 5. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • Comparisons to Andy Warhol's factory and historical shifts in art (e.g., photography) suggest that art has always balanced ideas and skill, and AI might represent another stage in this evolution.
  • • The notion of AI art as a form of "false scarcity" or simulacrum highlights deeper philosophical concerns about the nature of creativity and substance in art.
  • • Practical observations, such as AI scrapers impacting artists' websites and conventions banning AI art, underscore real-world tensions between traditional and AI-assisted art.
  • 6. **Conclusion**:
  • • The discussion reflects an ongoing debate about the place of AI in the creative world, with strong opinions on both sides. While some see AI as a tool that can complement human creativity, others worry it undermines the essence of art and the livelihoods of artists. The conversation highlights ethical, philosophical, and practical challenges that will likely continue as AI technologies evolve.
Three types of LLM workloads and how to serve them
• Article: https://modal.com/llm-almanac/workloads
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46707708
• Score: 73
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Open-source advancements by DeepSeek, Alibaba Qwen, vLLM, and SGLang are disrupting proprietary AI APIs, empowering engineers to optimize large language model (LLM) workloads independently.
  • • LLM workloads are categorized into offline (batch-focused, throughput-driven), online (low-latency, interactive), and semi-online (bursty, flexible) types, with tailored solutions like vLLM, SGLang, and advanced GPU setups for each.
  • • This shift demands deeper workload understanding, enabling engineers to architect scalable, efficient systems while leveraging open-source tools and cloud platforms.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion includes two distinct threads:
  • • The first thread involves a correction of a Latin quote. A user, "rippeltippel," points out an error in the phrase "Gallia est omnis divisor in partes tres," correcting it to "Gallia est omnis divisa in partes tres." The reply from "charles_irl" acknowledges the correction with gratitude and indicates an intention to fix the error ("oof ty, willfix").
  • • The sentiment in this thread is lighthearted and collaborative.
  • 2. The second thread revolves around a technical comment about using SGLang with tensor parallelism and speculative decoding on specific GPUs. The initial comment by "ZsoltT" humorously reacts to the jargon-heavy description with a simple "lord." In response, "charles_irl" apologizes for the dense terminology, explaining that the goal was to provide concrete recommendations based on first principles, such as roofline analysis, rather than vague statements. They also mention that the technical terms are later clarified and supported with diagrams.
  • • This thread reflects a mix of humor and constructive clarification, with a focus on making technical concepts accessible.
  • 3. Overall, the sentiment of the discussion is positive and cooperative, with participants engaging in both light corrections and technical clarifications in a respectful and constructive manner.
Satya Nadella: "We need to find something useful for AI"
• Article: https://www.pcgamer.com/software/ai/microsoft-ceo-warns-that-we-must-do-something-useful-with-ai-or-theyll-lose-social-permission-to-burn-electricity-on-it/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46718485
• Score: 62
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • • The productivity gains from using large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT are debated, with some users finding them convenient but not revolutionary, while others highlight issues like hallucinations and inaccuracies.
  • • Concerns about the hype surrounding AI and its practical utility are prevalent. Many commenters question whether AI has found genuinely transformative applications or if it's largely a bubble driven by investor pressure.
  • • Energy consumption, hardware costs, and resource usage for AI systems are criticized, with some commenters pointing out the environmental and economic impacts of the AI industry's growth.
  • • Specific use cases for AI are discussed, including customer service, software development, healthcare, and personal finance. While some see incremental benefits, others argue these applications are limited or flawed.
  • • Skepticism about the broader societal and economic implications of AI, including its potential to replace jobs and the erosion of trust due to hype and hallucinated outputs.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is general agreement that AI tools like ChatGPT are useful for specific tasks, such as coding assistance or summarizing information. However, opinions differ on whether these tools are truly revolutionary or just incremental improvements.
  • • Many commenters express frustration with the hallucination problem in LLMs, which can lead to wasted time and unreliable outputs. Some argue this undermines the claimed productivity gains.
  • • A divide exists between those who see AI as a transformative technology with vast potential and those who view it as overhyped and struggling to justify its costs.
  • • The sentiment around AI in healthcare is mixed, with some noting its potential for assisting doctors and automating tasks, while others emphasize the challenges of data quality, legal compliance, and the limitations of generative AI in this field.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion leans toward skepticism, with many commenters questioning the current state of AI, its practical utility, and the motivations behind its development and promotion.
  • • There is also a sense of frustration with the hype cycle and the perception that AI is being pushed as a solution without clearly defined problems to solve.
  • • Some optimism is present, particularly among users who have found specific, niche applications of AI to be genuinely helpful.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • A commenter highlights that AI tools like ChatGPT allow users to "run Google" on their own data, offering a novel capability that traditional search engines cannot match.
  • • Another user emphasizes that AI could be transformative in personal finance management, suggesting that a trustworthy, AI-driven budgeting tool could be a "killer app.
  • • Concerns are raised about the long-term sustainability of AI advancements, with one commenter predicting that free or cheap AI will eventually become ad-driven and less capable unless users pay a premium for quality.
  • 5. **Broader Observations**:
  • • Several commenters note the potential societal harm caused by the AI hype bubble, including resource consumption, eroded trust, and the promotion of unsafe or ineffective technologies.
  • • The discussion reflects a growing awareness of the limitations of generative AI and the need for more meaningful, impactful applications to justify the immense investment in the field.
Show HN: Retain – A unified knowledge base for all your AI coding conversations
• Article: https://github.com/BayramAnnakov/retain
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46710756
• Score: 41
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Retain is a macOS-native app that consolidates AI conversations from platforms like Claude Code, ChatGPT, and claude.ai into a local, searchable knowledge base, enabling intelligent learning extraction and persistent context building.
  • • Key features include multi-source sync, full-text search across 10k+ conversations, automatic preference detection, and CLAUDE.md export for seamless AI memory integration, all while prioritizing local data storage and privacy.
  • • Currently in beta, Retain aims to evolve from a personal memory OS to a system for automating workflows and managing versioned records, redefining how users interact with AI tools.

Discussion Highlights:

  • • The discussion centers around a new tool or feature that seems to integrate with AI coding tools, with a focus on local-first functionality and conversation aggregation/search capabilities.
  • • Several commenters expressed interest in trying the tool, with one mentioning it feels like it should be part of Claude Code, and another seeing it as a potential replacement for Anthropic's search feature due to dissatisfaction with their current app.
  • • There were some concerns and confusion about the concept of "local-first," particularly around whether data is stored locally or pulled from external servers. The creator clarified that local-first means user data is not stored on their servers.
  • • Some commenters noted platform limitations, with one mentioning they are Windows-only and another Linux-only, which may hinder their ability to use the tool. The creator acknowledged these limitations but did not provide solutions.
  • • Overall sentiment was positive, with commenters appreciating the tool's potential and expressing a willingness to try it, despite some platform constraints and questions about its functionality.

item.title: AI Agenda: Why Some Researchers at OpenAI, Thinking Machines and Amazon Want to Change How LLMs Are Trained
item.description:
AI Agenda
It seems like every AI researcher these days has lots of ideas around how to combat major shortcomings in the field, such as the “split-brain problem” (in which a model can incorrectly answer a question just because of the way the question is phrased), by developing new models that do “continual learning,” for instance.͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 22, 2026

AI Agenda
By Stephanie Palazzolo
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! I’d love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign up here.

Hello!

It seems like every AI researcher these days has lots of ideas around how to combat major shortcomings in the field, such as the “split-brain problem” (in which a model can incorrectly answer a question just because of the way the question is phrased), by developing new models that do “continual learning,” for instance.

AI researchers also tell me they’re interested in revamping the model training process. Some researchers, including Amazon’s David Luan, say the current order of steps of pretraining (giving it a broad, general knowledge of the world) before posttraining (honing its knowledge in specific domains) don’t make much sense. 

This order of steps has become the norm in AI because, in some ways, it makes intuitive sense: humans similarly require a general base of knowledge you learn during childhood before learning more specific skills later on in life.

But Luan says that if you know a model will be used for coding or helping with customer refunds, why spend so much effort teaching the model about completely irrelevant topics, like poetry or horticulture? 

His argument is that it makes more sense to use the pretraining process to expose the model to more curated data related to the task it is destined to handle. The idea is to prepare the model for its eventual purpose. 

Researchers from a variety of other major developers, including OpenAI and Thinking Machines Lab, agree. Some even think that AI developers should do away with separate teams for the different stages of model training and just consolidate everyone into a single training team.

If this comes to fruition, however, it will have important implications for the way AI is developed.

Researchers will have to decide what curated data they want to include earlier in the training process, which can affect what the model is and isn’t good at. (For instance, a decision to include more math and code and less prose data during early training could make the model worse at creative writing or speaking warmly to users.) 

This most likely would lead to a future of many specialized models trained on different datasets, rather than what’s most common today: researchers using the same pretrained model but making tweaks during posttraining to get it to perform better at different tasks.

Already, we’re seeing examples of places where such an approach could be helpful. As Sri, Amir and I wrote about here, one problem OpenAI is facing is that what consumers want out of ChatGPT—help with relatively simple questions and a friend to talk to—doesn’t align with the cutting-edge research the company is doing in areas like reasoning models to get to superintelligence, or AI that can help us colonize Mars or find new cures for diseases.

OpenAI is already acknowledging this divide by using a router to direct ChatGPT queries to be handled by different models depending on how complicated they are, and by creating specialized models like GPT-5-Codex (though all of the models are based on the same pretrained model). 

Doubling down on this by training completely different models for ChatGPT, scientific research or coding, for instance, would require the company to completely revamp its research team.

Microsoft Backs Photonics Startup

Investor enthusiasm has been mounting for startups that use light instead of electrons in hardware for data centers—specifically to use light to ferry data among chips in data centers. 

Neurophos is taking a different tack. The six-year-old startup designs chips that use light to perform the mathematical operations involved in running AI models. And it just raised $110 million in a Series A funding round led by Gates Frontier, Bill Gates’ venture firm, according to Patrick Bowen, co-founder and CEO of Neurophos.

M12, Microsoft’s venture firm, also participated in the round. Backing from Microsoft, one of the biggest cloud providers, is a sign of confidence in the technology.

“Modern AI inference demands monumental amounts of power and compute,” said Marc Tremblay, corporate vice president and technical fellow of core AI infrastructure at Microsoft in a statement. “We need a breakthrough in compute on par with the leaps we‘ve seen in AI models themselves, which is what Neurophos’ technology and high-talent density team is developing.”

The appeal of using light is that it could be much more energy-efficient than electrons for running AI models. The chip the startup expects to deliver in 2028 will be 50 times as fast and 50 times as efficient as an Nvidia Blackwell, said Bowen. 

The funding round also included participation from Carbon Direct Capital, Aramco Ventures, Bosch Ventures, Tectonic Ventures and Space Capital, DNX Ventures, Geometry, MetaVC Partners, Morgan Creek Capital, Silicon Catalyst Ventures, Mana Ventures and Gaingel.—Rocket Drew

Here’s what else is going on…

Claude Gets a Revamped Constitution

Anthropic yesterday released its new “constitution” for Claude, essentially, a document that provides guidelines for how the model should act and respond in more “gray area” situations. This is the first publicly-released update the company has made to its Claude constitution since it first released the document in 2023.

Compared to the original constitution, the updated version is less prescriptive and treats the model more like an intelligent entity with its own sense of good judgment by, for instance, explaining the reasoning behind the rules it provides rather than just listing them outright. Interestingly, the document also leaves room for the possibility that Claude has some sort of “consciousness” or “moral status,” a change from the original document.

Overheard

OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar said the company’s custom inference chip is being “taped out”—the final step before manufacturing—and touted the progress of its more than $500 billion Stargate infrastructure project in a panel at the World Economic Forum Wednesday.

On Stargate, which was announced one year ago, she said that the project is “well over halfway built out” and OpenAI is already training models on servers at Oracle’s Stargate campus. “It’s gone better than we all dreamed,” she said.

Deals and Debuts

See The Information’s Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

Lightning AI, which offers software for customizing AI models, and data center provider Voltage Park merged into a single company, still called Lightning AI, that is valued at over $2.5 billion.

Recommendation app Yelp on Wednesday said it agreed to acquire AI agent startup Hatch for $300 million, or roughly 12 times the startup’s annual recurring revenue.

Upscale AI, which provides networking equipment for AI data centers, raised $200 million in a Series A funding round led by Tiger Global, Premji Invest and Xora Innovation.

Zanskar, which uses AI to search for geothermal energy, raised $115 million in a Series C funding round led by Spring Lane Capital.

AheadComputing, which designs CPU chips for AI data centers, raised $30 million in a seed extension funding round led by Eclipse, Toyota Ventures and Cambium.

Google DeepMind is hiring the CEO and several top engineers from Hume AI, a startup developing voice AI models, as part of a licensing agreement. The terms of the deal weren’t disclosed.

Apple is developing an AI-powered wearable pin that could be released as early as 2027, The Information reported. Apple plans to bring more conversational capabilities to Siri, turning it more into a chatbot like ChatGPT, Bloomberg reported. Bloomberg also reported that Apple is in talks with Google about using the company’s cloud infrastructure, including its AI chips, tensor processing units, to launch the updated Siri.

Amazon-owned primary care chain One Medical said it is launching an AI health assistant.

Shopify has told merchants that use its commerce software that it will open up sales through AI chatbots like ChatGPT later this month, according to its site and communications with sellers.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is preparing for a trip to China later this month as the company works to regain its footing in this strategically important market, Bloomberg reported, citing a person with knowledge of the plans.

Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth said at a press conference that Meta Superintelligence Labs delivered its first AI models internally this month, Reuters reported.

The White House Council of Economic Advisers released a report on “Artificial Intelligence and the Great Divergence,” writing that “the advent of generative artificial intelligence based around large language models (LLMs) will initiate a new wave of profound economic transformation in the United States, promising significant boosts to productivity and growth.”

YouTube will work on managing AI “slop” videos on the site this year, while adding AI tools to generate short-form videos using your own likeness, CEO Neal Mohan wrote in his annual letter.

Microsoft announced Rho-alpha, a new AI model for powering robots, based on its Phi language models.

A message from ServiceNow

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNow® works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more
