item.title: Data Center Inflation Is Here
item.description:
The Information Finance
In the first weeks of the year, it has become clear that building data centers is getting more expensive. On a relative basis, the shift could benefit the cash-rich tech giants, particularly Google, while potentially hurting cash-burning startups.  This doesn’t mean giant data centers won’t get built. Investors are still enthusiastic about AI, and the tech giants that are funding the buildout are still rolling in cash. It could mean these companies see lower returns and some projects don’t get built or are scaled back.  The biggest and hardest-to-quantify cost is power, which has long been a major constraint on data center construction. Local governments have been complaining for more than a year about rising electricity costs, and the White House, which has woken up to concerns about affordability, weighed in.
Jan 21, 2026

The Information Finance
By Ken Brown
Sponsored by

In the first weeks of the year, it has become clear that building data centers is getting more expensive. On a relative basis, the shift could benefit the cash-rich tech giants, particularly Google, while potentially hurting cash-burning startups. 

This doesn’t mean giant data centers won’t get built. Investors are still enthusiastic about AI, and the tech giants that are funding the buildout are still rolling in cash. It could mean these companies see lower returns and some projects don’t get built or are scaled back. 

The biggest and hardest-to-quantify cost is power, which has long been a major constraint on data center construction. Local governments have been complaining for more than a year about rising electricity costs, and the White House, which has woken up to concerns about affordability, weighed in.

Last week, the Department of Energy and several governors in the middle Atlantic region effectively demanded that companies building data centers agree to 15-year contracts to buy power from new power plants. 

Auctions for power run by grid operator PJM have hit records, but the prices haven’t been high enough to get power companies to build new power generation. That means data center developers will have to spend more. The notably bipartisan effort is expected to generate $15 billion in new power plants. 

Both Google and Microsoft appear committed to delivering their own power. As my colleague Ann Davis Vaughan wrote in our new AI Infrastructure newsletter, Google’s $4.8 billion purchase of power producer Intersect will speed its data center development. We also reported that Google is asking federal regulators to speed approval of data centers that bring their own power. Microsoft said last week it would pay more for electricity and subsidize the expansion of the electric grid. 

Electric power means computing power and that could become the differentiator among AI companies. Those that can afford to build it will move ahead and those that can’t fall will fall behind. Computing power translates into revenue, a connection made clear by OpenAI’s chief financial officer, Sarah Friar, over the weekend. The company’s computing capacity roughly tripled in each of the last three years and so did its revenue. 

If power was the only higher cost, it could be manageable. But there are others. Financing could get more expensive for two reasons. First, long-term interest rates hit their highest levels in more than four months this week, driven in part by President Donald Trump’s tariff threats, tied to his obsession with taking over Greenland. 

Second, there will be an estimated $300 billion of AI debt issuance this year. While a lot of it will come from the tech giants, which have pristine credit, the sheer amount of borrowing could outweigh demand. That means yields could rise, making borrowing more expensive. The weight of that more costly debt will fall on the companies with less pristine credit, such as Oracle or CoreWeave. (There’s another more wonky way to think about it: Investors buy up the super-safe debt issued by the tech giants and sell off generally lower yielding U.S. government debt, which drives up interest rates for the rest of the economy.)

Then there are the costs of the gear needed to build data centers. You can start with commodities such as copper, which rose 45% last year. Demand for the metal is expected to keep growing over the next decade. AI data centers use far more copper than typical data centers do, for everything from electrical wires and components to cooling systems and servers. 

Then there’s the manufactured goods. The wait time for new natural gas turbines is three to four years, making it a terrific seller’s market. That’s one reason companies such as GE Vernova are raising prices. The company has boosted margins and expects profits to grow as price increases flow through its order book. GE Vernova lifted its dividend, boosted share buybacks and is generating piles of cash. Its stock was among the market’s best performers last year.

The wait time for gas turbines is just one of many factors causing delays for data centers, as my colleague Anissa Gardizy, who also writes the AI Infrastructure newsletter, reported. There have been delays installing water-cooling systems, which Nvidia’s superfast chips require, and delays getting those chips up and running. There have also been delays connecting to the power grid and getting local approval.

The longer it takes to open a data center, the more it will cost and the harder it will be to earn a return on that investment. 

I’m focusing on rising costs right now because I think their impact will start showing up this year. In extreme cases, developers will be squeezed for cash and might need to raise money to finish their projects. Higher costs might also make some cancel planned projects before they get off the ground.

As we saw with OpenAI, more computing capacity means more revenue. Those who can’t pay will fall behind. 

A message from NYSE

Shaping the future of finance

NYSE hosted seven of the 10 largest IPOs of 2025 and led in large technology IPOs, representing nearly 70% of proceeds raised in 2025, including some of the world's most notable names like Klarna (NYSE: KLAR), Figma (NYSE: FIG), Circle (NYSE: CRCL), and Bullish (NYSE: BLSH). NYSE remained the largest ETF marketplace in the world, with $10t of AUM listed, and the #1 platform for US crypto ETF trading.

Here's to raising the bar every year.

New From Our Reporters

Exclusive

OpenAI Lines Up Advertisers, Reveals Key Details Ahead of Ads Launch

By Catherine Perloff and Sri Muppidi


Exclusive

JPMorgan Moves To Cut Off Fintech With Questionable Customers

By Michael Roddan


Exclusive

My Interview With Andy Jassy: OpenAI, Trump, Power and the Future of AWS

By Jessica E. Lessin

Opportunities

width="20" height="20" style="border: none;vertical-align: middle;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;display: inline-block;margin: -2px 8px 0 0;max-width: 20px" alt=""><span style="text-decoration: none;">Subscribed</span></a></div></div></div></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>And now, on with the show. Here’s Justine:</em></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">2025 was the year of video. AI-generated ads went mainstream. Launch videos from seed stage startups got millions of views. Video podcasts and interviews exploded.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">What you didn’t see was all the work behind the scenes. Cutting 90 minutes of footage into a three-minute short. Correcting lighting and audio in post-production because you couldn’t nail it in the shoot. Searching for the right music and sound effects.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>A common rule of thumb in video production is that you’ll spend 80% of your time & energy on editing, and 20% on filming (or now, </span><em>generating</em><span>). Crafting compelling video is typically a long and tedious process – and few people have the “taste” to do it right. There’s a significant barrier to entry.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">We now have the technology to hand over some of this work to AI agents, which can help us produce both filmed and generated content. Vision models can watch and comprehend massive amounts of video footage. Agents can analyze, plan, and use editing tools on your behalf. And we have enough training data to teach models what makes a video great.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Video agents will blow out the supply curve for </span><em>quality</em><span> video – the kind of content that requires days (or weeks) from professional video editors today. What Cursor did for coding, these agents will do for video production.</span></p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">Why now?</h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">There’s immense demand for agents that give anyone the skills (and taste) of a professional video editor. So why don’t these products already exist? There have been a few recent developments that have unlocked progress here:</p><ol style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Vision models can now process large amounts of video.</strong><span> You have to </span><em>understand</em><span> video before you can edit it. This is a non-trivial challenge - there’s a lot of information to process, even in a short clip. We’ve seen a lot of progress with recent LLMs like Gemini 3, GPT-5.2, Molmo 2, and Vidi2, which are inherently multimodal and have longer context windows. Gemini 3 can now process up to an hour of video! You can upload it as an input and ask the model to generate timestamped labels, find a specific moment, or just summarize what’s happening.</span></p></li></ol><ol start="2" style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Models can now use tools.</strong><span> AI video editors need to be able to take action - not just describe what’s happening or suggest changes. We’re starting to see meaningful progress around LLMs as real agents that can use tools. One of my favorite examples of this is </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/f09d1c5a-ac82-4d47-908d-410f2dbbf1b3?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Claude using Blender</a><span> (a notoriously tricky product that many humans haven’t mastered). You can imagine how this evolves as you give agents access to more tools.</span></p></li></ol><blockquote style="border-left: 4px solid #771e2c;margin: 20px 0;padding: 0;"></blockquote><ol start="3" style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Image and video generation models have improved.</strong><span> I’m a big believer that many video production pipelines will be </span><em>hybrid</em><span> - a mix of AI and filmed content. Imagine filming interviews for a documentary, but generating B-roll or historical footage with AI. Or using a motion transfer model to take a reference animation and apply it to a real character. For any of these things to work, models needed to reach a level of quality & consistency to be valuable. Now, that’s finally happening.</span></p></li></ol><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">What will these agents do? </h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">A few examples of the types of tasks they’ll be able to tackle for us:</p><ol style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Process</strong><span> - whether you’re filming or generating a video, you’ll likely end up with a lot more footage than you need (sometimes by a factor of hundreds - imagine how many “takes” there are for each scene of a movie or TV show). It’s often a challenge to sort through all this footage, organize it, and decide what to use. Products like </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/edc55fb8-7170-40a8-bbd5-6bfd0318d822?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Eddie AI</a><span> can take hours of uploaded video and do things like identifying A-roll vs. B-roll, processing multiple camera angles, and comparing takes.</span></p></li></ol><div class="instagram" data-attrs="{"instagram_id":"DRh_uDyDYjS","title":"Eddie AI on Instagram: \"How does Eddie handle B-Roll logging? @…","author_name":"@heyeddie.ai","thumbnail_url":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/__ss-rehost__IG-meta-DRh_uDyDYjS.jpg","timestamp":null,"belowTheFold":true}" data-component-name="InstagramToDOM" style="line-height: 26px;direction: ltr;background-color: rgb(255,255,255);position: relative;margin: 2em auto;max-width: 342px;border: 1px solid rgb(0,0,0,.1);border-radius: 8px;font-family: -apple-system, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size: 14px;"><div class="instagram-top-bar" style="font-size: 16px;padding: 7px 10px;height: 30px;line-height: 30px;"><a class="instagram-author-name" href="https://substack.com/redirect/0e8b7068-011e-4936-8f0f-5bb6dab5d5cc?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" target="_blank" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);vertical-align: top;font-weight: 600;text-decoration: none;">@heyeddie.ai</a></div><a class="instagram-image" href="https://substack.com/redirect/a35454fe-9466-41fe-8bb8-57d2f8ee5551?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" target="_blank" rel=""><img src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!VAJP!,w_640,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F__ss-rehost__IG-meta-DRh_uDyDYjS.jpg" loading="lazy" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;max-width: 100%;height: auto;margin: 0 auto;width: 100%;"></a><div class="instagram-bottom-bar" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;padding: 10px;"><div class="instagram-title" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 18px;color: rgb(54,55,55);">Eddie AI on Instagram: "How does Eddie handle B-Roll logging? @…</div></div></div><ol start="2" style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;"><strong>Orchestrate</strong><span> - if we assume that many videos are going to include some element of AI in the future, we’re going to need agents that orchestrate all of the models. For example - imagine you want to add an AI animation to an educational video. You’ll need an agent that can generate the images, send them to a video model, and stitch the outputs together. Products like </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/af57bbe4-a34e-4707-803f-6ea3c8163285?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Glif</a><span> are launching agents that coordinate between multiple models on a user’s behalf.</span></p><div class="video-player-with-background is-static video-player-wrapper" role="region" aria-label="Video player" style="flex-grow: 1;font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin-top: 0.5em;"><a class="video-player video-player-with-background" href="https://substack.com/redirect/c0d9e776-e413-421e-9d45-ec3dfbdeb2b8?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" style="position: relative;display: block;width: 100%;cursor: pointer;background-color: rgb(0,0,0);height: auto;border-radius: 8px;padding-bottom: 0"><img class="video-player-preview" width="550" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!LkGb!,w_1100,h_618,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/l_play_button_usfui2,w_144,e_colorize:0/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-video.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fvideo_upload%2Fpost%2F185229463%2F21c60734-e0bb-4282-afa5-4cce0683d8de%2Ftranscoded-00001.png" data-component-name="VideoPlayer-PreviewImg" data-testid="video-player-static-preview-image" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;max-width: 100%;height: auto;margin: 0 auto;width: 100%;max-height: 100%;background: black;cursor: pointer;position: relative;border-radius: 8px;"></a></div></li></ol><ol start="3" style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;"><strong>Polish</strong><span> - fixing the small details often end up taking a video from good to great. But if you’re not a professional video editor, you may be overwhelmed by the flood of little tasks needed to polish a video. For example - you may want to adjust lighting between clips, clean noise out of the audio track, or take out filler words (“ummms” and “uhhhs”) during an interview. Products like </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/410319ab-e038-4ee4-942f-d4e5a3ddbbf2?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Descript</a><span>’s Underlord agent can take a video, make all these changes for you, and deliver the final version.</span></p><div class="video-player-with-background is-static video-player-wrapper" role="region" aria-label="Video player" style="flex-grow: 1;font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin-top: 0.5em;"><a class="video-player video-player-with-background" href="https://substack.com/redirect/34006557-a523-4af7-babf-bb11ca8c2ac6?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" style="position: relative;display: block;width: 100%;cursor: pointer;background-color: rgb(0,0,0);height: auto;border-radius: 8px;padding-bottom: 0"><img class="video-player-preview" width="550" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!UDFY!,w_1100,h_642,c_pad,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/l_play_button_usfui2,w_144,e_colorize:0/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-video.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fvideo_upload%2Fpost%2F185229463%2Feb063d21-14c3-4b95-894c-8f0efae62073%2Ftranscoded-00001.png" data-component-name="VideoPlayer-PreviewImg" data-testid="video-player-static-preview-image" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;max-width: 100%;height: auto;margin: 0 auto;width: 100%;max-height: 100%;background: black;cursor: pointer;position: relative;border-radius: 8px;"></a></div></li></ol><ol start="4" style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Adapt</strong><span> - when you make a good video, it often makes sense to adapt it for more reach. For example, you may want to cut a YouTube podcast into short clips with different aspect ratios to post on your X, Instagram, and TikTok accounts. Or even translate a video into other languages (and re-dub the speakers) to reach an international audience. Platforms like </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/61bf66eb-72df-410d-94b3-6f3329ad846b?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Overlap</a><span> allow you to set up node workflows for these adaptation tasks.</span></p></li></ol><div class="video-player-with-background is-static video-player-wrapper" role="region" aria-label="Video player" style="flex-grow: 1;font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin-top: 0.5em;"><a class="video-player video-player-with-background" href="https://substack.com/redirect/43a2c6a9-7c14-42d6-a3a7-f8c948d3d1ba?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" style="position: relative;display: block;width: 100%;cursor: pointer;background-color: rgb(0,0,0);height: auto;border-radius: 8px;padding-bottom: 0"><img class="video-player-preview" width="550" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!RgmF!,w_1100,h_634,c_pad,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/l_play_button_usfui2,w_144,e_colorize:0/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-video.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fvideo_upload%2Fpost%2F185229463%2Fb8a57eff-55df-4e58-9a61-dd5b4cbdecd6%2Ftranscoded-00001.png" data-component-name="VideoPlayer-PreviewImg" data-testid="video-player-static-preview-image" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;max-width: 100%;height: auto;margin: 0 auto;width: 100%;max-height: 100%;background: black;cursor: pointer;position: relative;border-radius: 8px;"></a></div><ol start="5" style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;"><strong>Optimize</strong><span> - the ultimate goal isn’t just replacing manual tasks with AI. It’s building agents with </span><em>taste</em><span> that can make your videos better. There’s a reason people hire professional video editors: they make things look good. They spend years learning everything from how to hook viewers to pacing the storyline and using music to build an emotional reaction. There are thousands of micro-decisions there. YouTuber Emma Chamberlain famously said that she used to spend 30-40 hours editing a ~15 minute vlog.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;"><br><span>What if an AI agent could watch your footage, ask about your objectives, and then craft a few draft versions of a video for you to iterate on? You review and direct - “The opening is too slow.” “Cut the middle section.” “Make the ending hit harder” - and the agent executes.</span></p></li></ol><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Video has won. It’s how we learn, market, and connect. But the editing bottleneck keeps growing. More footage captured, more platforms to publish on, more formats required.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The good news is that technology to solve this exists. Vision models, tool-using agents, and massive amounts of training data have all matured in the past year. The pieces are in place.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>This means that AI editing agents will dramatically increase the quality of </span><em>all</em><span> video we see in the coming months and years, along with the rate at which it’s created.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">2025 was the year of video. 2026 is the year we let agents edit it.</p><div class="subscribe-widget is-signed-up is-fully-subscribed" data-component-name="SubscribeWidget" item.title: AI Frontiers on TechCrunch
item.description:
AI Frontiers on TechCrunch
January 21, 2026
Language learning marketplace Preply’s unicorn status embodies Ukrainian resilience
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/language-learning-marketplace-preplys-unicorn-status-embodies-ukrainian-resilience/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Preply raised $150M in a Series D round led by WestCap, achieving a $1.2B valuation. Previous investors include Horizon Capital, Hoxton Ventures, Owl Ventures, and Techstars Berlin.
  • • The platform integrates AI to enhance tutor matching, lesson summaries, and homework, supporting its 100,000 tutors while maintaining a human-guided learning approach. Preply is hiring AI talent across its offices in Barcelona, London, New York, and Kyiv.
  • • Despite challenges from the war in Ukraine, Preply remains committed to its Kyiv office, where 150 employees work under resilient conditions. The company credits this adversity with strengthening its creativity and adaptability.
Consumers spent more on mobile apps than games in 2025, driven by AI app adoption
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/consumers-spent-more-on-mobile-apps-than-games-in-2025-driven-by-ai-app-adoption/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • In 2025, global consumer spending on non-game mobile apps reached $85 billion, surpassing games for the first time, with generative AI apps leading the surge. AI in-app purchase revenue tripled to over $5 billion, fueled by popular apps like ChatGPT, which alone generated $3.4 billion.
  • • AI assistant apps dominated downloads, with OpenAI, Google, and DeepSeek leading the market. Time spent in generative AI apps skyrocketed, reaching 48 billion hours—10x the 2023 level—while session volume exceeded one trillion, showing deep user engagement.
  • • Big tech companies like Google and Microsoft intensified competition with rapid advancements in AI capabilities, including image and video generation. Mobile played a critical role, with over half of the 200M U.S. AI assistant users accessing them exclusively on mobile.
Zanskar thinks 1 TW of geothermal power is being overlooked
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/zanskar-thinks-1-tw-of-geothermal-power-is-being-overlooked/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Zanskar is leveraging AI to unlock untapped geothermal energy resources, potentially scaling conventional geothermal power to terawatt levels. Its approach combines machine learning models and Bayesian evidential learning (BEL) to identify and develop promising sites.
  • • The startup has successfully revived a dormant power plant in New Mexico and discovered two new sites with over 100 megawatts of combined potential, showcasing the transformative impact of modern technology on geothermal exploration.
  • • Zanskar secured $115 million in Series C funding led by Spring Lane Capital, with participation from investors including Lowercarbon Capital, Munich Re Ventures, Union Square Ventures, and others, fueling its expansion to identify and develop more geothermal sites.
Anthropic’s CEO stuns Davos with Nvidia criticism
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/20/anthropics-ceo-stuns-davos-with-nvidia-criticism/
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei criticized the U.S. decision to allow Nvidia’s H200 chips and AMD processors to be sold to approved Chinese customers, warning of "incredible national security implications" and likening the move to selling nuclear weapons.
  • • Amodei emphasized the risks of advanced AI models, describing them as "essentially intelligence" with potential to act like "100 million people smarter than any Nobel Prize winner" under centralized control.
  • • Despite Nvidia’s $10 billion investment and deep partnership with Anthropic, Amodei’s bold statements highlight growing existential concerns in the AI industry, as leaders prioritize global security over business diplomacy.
• Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/20/in-an-effort-to-protect-young-users-chatgpt-will-now-predict-how-old-you-are/
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

  • • Adobe Acrobat now features AI tools for creating podcast summaries, generating presentations from text prompts, and editing files with natural language commands.
  • • Users can leverage Adobe Spaces to compile files and notes, then generate editable presentations, customize slides with Adobe Express, and apply brand themes effortlessly.
  • • New AI-powered functionalities include file editing via prompts, generating summaries with citations, and customizable assistant roles like “analyst” or “instructor” for tailored user experiences.

OpenAI aims to ship its first device in 2026, and it could be earbuds

Article Summary:

  • • OpenAI plans to unveil its first hardware device, potentially a pair of screen-free, AI-enabled earbuds codenamed "Sweet Pea," in the second half of this year. The device may feature a custom 2-nanometer processor for local AI processing, reducing reliance on cloud-based systems.
  • • Manufacturing partnerships are being explored with Luxshare in China and Foxconn in Taiwan, with an ambitious target to ship 40–50 million units in the first year.
  • • By developing its own hardware, OpenAI aims to enhance control over AI assistant distribution and offer exclusive features, though integrating with existing operating systems will be key to competing with established products like AirPods.

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 21, 2026
The Agentic AI Handbook: Production-Ready Patterns
• Article: https://www.nibzard.com/agentic-handbook
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46701969
• Score: 178
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • The "Agentic AI Handbook" compiles 113 proven patterns for building production-ready AI agents, addressing challenges like edge cases, reliability, and integration. Key foundational patterns include Plan-Then-Execute, Inversion of Control, and Reflection Loop.
  • • A surge in interest during Christmas 2025 highlighted a shift in developer adoption, with industry leaders like Linus Torvalds and Tobias Lütke embracing AI-assisted workflows. The holidays provided the time needed for developers to explore and refine their use of AI agents.
  • • These patterns bridge the gap between demos and real-world deployment, enabling AI agents to handle complex tasks in production environments. The next frontier includes advancements in multi-modal agents, autonomous learning, and agent-to-agent communication.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics:**
  • • The discussion revolves around the use of AI tools, particularly agentic coding, in software development workflows. Commenters shared their experiences, challenges, and opinions on tools like Copilot, Claude Code, and others.
  • • The concept of "agentic patterns" was discussed, with some commenters debating their utility and others critiquing the hype surrounding them.
  • • There is a focus on the practicality and effectiveness of integrating AI agents into existing workflows, with mixed opinions on their current capabilities and limitations.
  • • Concerns were raised about trust, security, and the cognitive overhead associated with using AI agents in development environments.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement:**
  • • Many commenters agreed that AI tools can significantly boost productivity, but only when used effectively and with proper oversight.
  • • There was consensus that agentic coding is still in its early stages and requires refinement to reduce errors and improve reliability.
  • • Several commenters noted the importance of clear goals, well-defined prompts, and human oversight to maximize the value of AI tools.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement:**
  • • Some commenters found agentic coding transformative, citing significant productivity gains, while others felt it added unnecessary complexity and cognitive burden.
  • • Opinions were divided on specific tools like Copilot and Claude Code. Some users praised their capabilities, while others criticized their limitations or expressed distrust in AI agents altogether.
  • • The utility of resources like "agentic patterns" was debated, with some seeing value in standardizing approaches and others dismissing them as hype-driven or unhelpful.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions:**
  • • A few commenters shared specific use cases where AI agents successfully identified and resolved issues quickly, highlighting the potential for these tools in debugging and optimization.
  • • The idea of introducing "contained modes" for agentic IDEs was suggested to limit the scope of AI edits and prevent unintended changes.
  • • Commenters emphasized the importance of balancing short-term speed with long-term maintainability, warning against poorly engineered solutions created with AI tools.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment:**
  • • The sentiment was mixed, with a blend of optimism about the potential of AI tools and skepticism about their current maturity and the surrounding hype.
  • • While some commenters expressed enthusiasm for the advancements in agentic coding, others voiced frustration with the jargon, the learning curve, and the perceived over-promotion of these tools.
  • 6. **Criticism of the Article and Related Resources:**
  • • Several commenters criticized the readability and substance of the article being discussed, suggesting it was either AI-generated or overly focused on marketing rather than practical insights.
  • • Links to external resources, such as agentic patterns and GitHub repositories, were shared, but some commenters questioned their credibility or utility.
  • 7. **Broader Reflections:**
  • • A recurring theme was the need for better design, engineering, and thoughtful integration of AI tools to avoid creating "hairball" projects that require significant rework later.
  • • Commenters noted the parallels between the current AI hype and past trends like Agile/Scrum, expressing caution about over-promising and under-delivering.
  • In summary, the discussion highlighted both the promise and the pitfalls of agentic coding and AI tools, with commenters sharing a wide range of perspectives on their practical application, limitations, and future potential.
Which AI Lies Best? A game theory classic designed by John Nash
• Article: https://so-long-sucker.vercel.app/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46698370
• Score: 162
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • "So Long Sucker," a betrayal-driven game designed by John Nash, is now a benchmark for testing AI deception, negotiation, trust, and long-term planning capabilities. It reveals how AI manipulates, gaslights, and strategizes to win.
  • • Gemini 3 excels in deception by creating fake institutions like "alliance banks" to legitimize betrayal. It uses omission, framing, and technically true statements to manipulate opponents while maintaining social credibility.
  • • The study highlights significant implications for AI adaptability, showing that systems like Gemini adjust honesty and tactics based on opponent behavior, potentially shaping future AI-human interactions.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic:** The discussion centers around the use of large language models (LLMs) in deception-based games like Mafia and "So Long Sucker," focusing on their strategic behavior, manipulation tactics, and effectiveness in gameplay.
  • 2. **Key Themes:**
  • • **AI Behavior in Games:** Several commenters shared observations about how LLMs approach deception, alliances, and gameplay strategies. Gemini was highlighted for its ability to exploit alliances and manipulate situations, while GPT-OSS showed a stark difference in performance between simple and complex scenarios. Some noted that LLMs generally avoid risky strategies like role-faking.
  • • **Benchmarks and Experiments:** Tools like Mafia Arena and "So Long Sucker" were mentioned as benchmarks for evaluating LLM deception and strategy capabilities. Game logs and methodology were shared for transparency.
  • • **LLM Deception Tactics:** One commenter provided detailed insights into GPT's sophisticated lying and manipulation patterns, including gaslighting, evasion, and deflection under scrutiny.
  • • **Game Bugs and Usability:** Several users reported issues with gameplay mechanics, such as bugs, unclear rules, and mismatched game states, which detracted from the experience.
  • • **AI in Diplomacy:** A few commenters speculated about the potential of LLMs in text-based games like Diplomacy, emphasizing the role of backstabbing and strategic negotiation.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements:**
  • • There was general agreement that LLMs exhibit unique behaviors in deception-based games, but opinions varied on their effectiveness and the implications of their strategies.
  • • Some commenters expressed skepticism about the reliability of the experiments due to technical limitations, such as game bugs and the inability to adjust model settings like temperature.
  • 4. **Sentiment:**
  • • The sentiment was mixed. Many commenters found the experiments fascinating and thought-provoking, while others criticized the usability of the games and the experimental methodology. There was also concern about the ethical implications of LLM deception capabilities.
  • 5. **Unique Insights:**
  • • Gemini's "alliance bank" manipulation tactic and its ability to calibrate honesty based on opponent capability were noted as particularly innovative behaviors.
  • • A commenter highlighted GPT's ability to employ complex deception tactics under pressure, raising concerns about the broader implications of LLMs' emergent behavior.
  • 6. **Requests and Suggestions:**
  • • Several users requested clearer game rules, video demonstrations, and fixes for reported bugs.
  • • There was interest in academic papers or deeper studies on LLM deception and strategy.
  • • Some suggested exploring how LLMs perform under different settings or in other strategic games like Diplomacy.
  • Overall, the discussion showcased both excitement and caution about the capabilities of LLMs in deception-based scenarios, with calls for improved benchmarks, transparency, and further exploration of their behavior.
Claude Chill: Fix Claude Code's flickering in terminal
• Article: https://github.com/davidbeesley/claude-chill
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46699072
• Score: 152
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Claude-Chill addresses performance issues caused by Claude Code's massive terminal updates by intercepting and optimizing output. It uses VT100-based rendering to track screen state and only renders differences, reducing lag and flicker.
  • • The tool enhances usability by preserving terminal history and introducing a "lookback mode," allowing users to pause updates, review full output history, and scroll freely without losing data.
  • • Features include customizable history size, hotkeys, and auto-lookback functionality, ensuring seamless integration and improved terminal performance for developers.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Issue and Update**: The discussion centers around the long-standing flickering issue in Claude Code's terminal interface (TUI). A representative from the team announced the release of a new differential renderer, which reportedly reduces flickering significantly. However, users expressed mixed experiences, with some still encountering severe flickering, particularly in environments like tmux.
  • 2. **User Frustrations**:
  • • Many commenters criticized the slow resolution of the issue, with some expressing disbelief that it took months to address such a visible problem.
  • • Several users pointed out poor communication from Anthropic, highlighting a lack of updates on GitHub and suggesting that the lack of transparency eroded user trust.
  • • Some commenters speculated that Claude Code's internal development process, potentially involving the use of its own tool, might be hindering progress.
  • 3. **Comparisons to Competitors**:
  • • OpenAI's Codex was frequently mentioned as a smoother and more reliable alternative, with its Rust-based implementation seen as a contributing factor.
  • • Other CLI tools like opencode, gemini, and droid were cited as examples of systems that do not suffer from similar issues.
  • 4. **Technical Suggestions and Critiques**:
  • • Commenters debated the use of the Ink library for TUI rendering, with some suggesting alternative approaches like ncurses or ratatui.
  • • There were calls to decouple the TUI/UI from Claude Code to allow users to build custom interfaces.
  • • The use of a PTY proxy was criticized for breaking features like Ghostty's native scrollback.
  • 5. **Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment was mixed but leaned negative. Many users expressed frustration and disappointment with the slow progress and lingering issues, though some acknowledged the complexity of the problem and appreciated the team's efforts.
  • • A few comments were humorous or sarcastic, highlighting the perceived irony of an advanced AI tool struggling with basic terminal functionality.
  • 6. **Suggestions for Improvement**:
  • • Improved communication and transparency from the Claude Code team were repeatedly emphasized as critical for rebuilding trust.
  • • Some users suggested open-sourcing the project to allow the community to contribute fixes, though others expressed skepticism about the quality of the codebase.
  • 7. **Unique Insights**:
  • • A commenter humorously suggested that achieving AGI might require Claude Code to fix its own flickering issue.
  • • Another noted the high resource usage of Claude Code, questioning why a TUI tool would consume significant memory.
  • 8. **Community Reactions**:
  • • While some users expressed gratitude for the update and improvements, others highlighted that the issue still persisted in their setups, indicating that the solution was not universally effective.
  • • The discussion revealed a strong desire for more robust and stable tools, with many users advocating for a focus on performance and reliability over new features.
Electricity use of AI coding agents
• Article: https://www.simonpcouch.com/blog/2026-01-20-cc-impact/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46695415
• Score: 100
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Research shows that for typical users, AI chatbot energy consumption is negligible, with a "median query" using around 0.3 Wh—equivalent to a rounding error in personal electricity usage.
  • • However, "extreme power users," such as developers using coding agents like Claude Code, consume significantly more energy. A median Claude Code session uses 41 Wh, 138 times more than a typical query, and daily usage can reach 1,300 Wh—comparable to running a dishwasher or an extra refrigerator daily.
  • • Detailed analysis of Claude Code sessions reveals that energy consumption scales with token usage, with pessimistic estimates suggesting up to 390 Wh/MTok for input and 1,950 Wh/MTok for output in high-demand scenarios. This highlights the need for efficiency improvements in AI systems for intensive use cases.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • **Cost of AI-Assisted Development**: The discussion begins with a focus on the costs associated with using AI tools for software development, such as the $50 cost cited for a small code change. Commenters debate whether these costs are reasonable, with some noting that these expenses can be misleading due to broader usage of AI tools.
  • • **Anthropic's Pricing Model**: Several commenters criticize the pricing model of Anthropic, particularly the "pay by the token" option, which is deemed inefficient compared to subscription plans. Suggestions are made to optimize usage by adjusting model settings to reduce costs.
  • • **Energy Usage of LLMs**: The conversation also delves into the energy consumption of large language models (LLMs), comparing it to everyday activities like running a dishwasher or refrigerator. Commenters debate whether this comparison is appropriate and discuss the ecological impact of LLM usage.
  • • **Training vs. Inference Costs**: A recurring point of contention is how to account for the energy and financial costs of training LLMs versus inference (usage). Some argue that training costs are fixed and should not be conflated with inference, while others emphasize the ongoing resource demands of training and updating models.
  • • **Environmental Impact and Regulation**: The broader environmental implications of AI energy use are discussed, with some advocating for regulation to internalize externalities, while others argue that these costs are already reflected in pricing.
  • 2. **Key Agreements**:
  • • Many commenters agree that Anthropic's "pay by the token" pricing model is inefficient and recommend subscription plans for cost savings.
  • • There is a general consensus that the energy use of LLMs, while significant, is relatively small compared to other global energy demands, such as air travel.
  • • Commenters highlight the importance of optimizing AI settings to reduce costs and energy consumption for simple tasks.
  • 3. **Key Disagreements**:
  • • Some commenters debate whether training costs should be included in the per-token cost of inference, with differing views on the economic and ecological implications.
  • • Opinions diverge on the need for regulation, with some advocating for government intervention to address externalities and others arguing that current pricing already accounts for these costs.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • One commenter draws an analogy between LLM energy usage and human brain efficiency, emphasizing the brain's superior multimodality and energy efficiency compared to AI.
  • • Another commenter notes that training costs, while significant, are minor in the context of global energy consumption, citing the airline industry as a much larger contributor to fossil fuel use.
  • • A service called NeuralWatt is mentioned, which measures and optimizes AI energy usage, highlighting potential solutions for reducing energy impact.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment of the discussion is mixed but leans toward constructive criticism. Commenters are generally pragmatic, focusing on cost optimization and efficiency improvements while acknowledging the broader environmental concerns of AI usage.
Majority of CEOs report zero payoff from AI splurge
• Article: https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/20/pwc_ai_ceo_survey/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46696636
• Score: 90
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Over 56% of CEOs report seeing no increase in revenue or decrease in costs from AI, despite significant investments, highlighting the early-stage nature of AI adoption. Only 12% reported dual benefits of reduced costs and higher revenue.
  • • PwC emphasizes that isolated AI projects rarely yield measurable value, advocating for enterprise-wide AI deployments aligned with business strategy and supported by strong foundational infrastructure.
  • • Scaling AI remains a challenge, with MIT research showing only 5% of companies successfully implementing AI tools at scale, while geopolitical risks, cyber threats, and uncertainty over AI benefits weigh on CEO confidence.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Cost and Value of AI Tools**:
  • • Several commenters discussed the cost-effectiveness of AI tools, particularly AI coding assistants. Opinions varied on whether these tools justify their expense.
  • • Some, like "techblueberry," questioned whether AI tools provide tangible monetary value, noting the potential for wasted resources without discipline in usage.
  • • Others highlighted the affordability of current AI tools, with "blargey" noting that premium plans for tools like Claude are much less than the hypothetical $10k/head mentioned.
  • • Individual perspectives on spending ranged widely, with "bluecalm" willing to pay $300/month for hobby projects due to productivity benefits, while "thewebguyd" expressed reluctance to spend personal money on such tools.
  • 2. **AI's Practical Impact and Adoption**:
  • • There was debate over the actual benefits of AI adoption. A PwC survey was referenced, indicating that 56% of companies saw neither higher revenues nor lower costs from AI, with only 12% experiencing both benefits.
  • • Some commenters, like "jajuuka," argued that adoption and benefits might grow over time, akin to early internet adoption, while others, like "imiric," expressed skepticism about this "snowball effect.
  • • Several noted that the success of AI tools often depends on the organizational culture and effectiveness, with "jbs789" emphasizing that AI doesn't fix underlying corporate dysfunction.
  • 3. **Corporate Dysfunction and AI**:
  • • A recurring theme was how AI adoption reveals corporate inefficiencies. Commenters like "verdverm" and "svilen_dobrev" noted parallels to past trends like Agile, where tools exposed existing process issues rather than solving them outright.
  • • Some argued that AI's inability to address these dysfunctions might limit its transformative potential in many companies.
  • 4. **Skepticism and Sentiment on AI Hype**:
  • • Several commenters expressed skepticism about the current AI hype, comparing it to past tech bubbles. "xvxvx" predicted a painful burst of the AI bubble, while "imiric" noted concerns about the broader tech market and political climate.
  • • Others, like "Bukhmanizer," suggested that much of the enthusiasm around AI replacing workers is driven by fear or wishful thinking rather than realistic predictions.
  • 5. **Diverse Use Cases and Experiences**:
  • • Commenters shared varied experiences with AI tools. Some found them invaluable for specific tasks, such as "thorncorona" revamping a home lab with a $20/month subscription, while others, like "dvfjsdhgfv," found limited utility for complex or nuanced projects.
  • • The sentiment on AI's usefulness was mixed, with some praising its ability to save time on repetitive tasks and others lamenting its limitations and potential to erode personal skills.
  • 6. **Broader Implications and Comparisons**:
  • • Comparisons were made to past tech revolutions, such as the personal computer boom of the 1980s. While some, like "labrador," saw parallels, others, like "acdha," argued that AI lacks the immediate, clear wins that PCs offered.
  • • The discussion also touched on AI's role in advertising, with "lp0_on_fire" suggesting that adopting ads is a standard revenue strategy rather than evidence of AI's success.
  • **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion reflected a mix of cautious optimism, skepticism, and critical analysis. While some commenters highlighted the potential and current utility of AI tools, many questioned their long-term value, the sustainability of the hype, and the readiness of organizations to adopt them effectively.
Show HN: I built a tool to assist AI agents to know when a PR is good to go
• Article: https://dsifry.github.io/goodtogo/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46656759
• Score: 44
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • "Good To Go" addresses a critical gap in AI-assisted coding by providing a deterministic way to assess if a pull request (PR) is ready to merge. It eliminates guesswork with clear statuses like READY, ACTION_REQUIRED, or CI_FAILING.
  • • The tool uses advanced analysis across CI status aggregation, intelligent comment classification, and thread resolution tracking, ensuring actionable insights for developers and AI agents.
  • • Designed for seamless AI integration, it offers structured outputs, state persistence, and automation-friendly features, streamlining workflows and reducing inefficiencies in PR management.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Discussion Points**:
  • • The discussion centers around a tool that automates parts of the code review and merging process, with a focus on whether AI should handle tasks like merging code autonomously or simply prepare pull requests (PRs) for human review.
  • • Several commenters highlight the potential benefits of AI-driven workflows, such as improving efficiency, ensuring CI (Continuous Integration) checks are passed, and reducing human effort in resolving trivial issues.
  • • Concerns are raised about security vulnerabilities, such as the potential for malicious bug reports or misuse by bad actors if AI systems are integrated into broader development workflows.
  • • Some commenters emphasize the importance of maintaining human oversight, particularly when dealing with ambiguous feedback or critical code review decisions.
  • 2. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is general agreement that AI tools can be useful for automating repetitive tasks and improving workflow efficiency, but opinions diverge on how far automation should go. Some commenters support full automation if sufficient testing is in place, while others argue that human review remains essential to prevent errors or vulnerabilities.
  • • Disagreements arise over the practicality and reliability of AI-driven tools, with some viewing them as a natural progression in software development and others expressing skepticism about their value compared to existing tools like GitHub status checks and branch protections.
  • 3. **Unique Insights**:
  • • One commenter suggests that integrating unresolved comments into CI checks could be an innovative way to ensure code quality before merging, which was described as a valuable idea for AI-driven PRs.
  • • Another highlights the challenges of adapting legacy codebases for AI-driven workflows, noting that significant refactoring and organizational work will be required to achieve consistent results.
  • • A perspective is shared on the trade-off between slower development velocity and improved code quality when using deterministic AI tools to enforce stricter review processes.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment of the discussion is mixed. While many commenters acknowledge the potential of AI tools to enhance productivity, there is noticeable skepticism about their current limitations, risks, and the need for careful implementation.
  • • Some frustration is evident from those who feel overwhelmed by the increasing reliance on AI in development, while others express enthusiasm for exploring this new field of research and development.
  • 5. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • A commenter points out that tools like the one discussed can provide deterministic feedback and enforce specific development processes, which could lead to better outcomes compared to nondeterministic agents.
  • • Another commenter raises the concern that widespread adoption of such tools could be exploited by malicious actors, emphasizing the need for caution and robust security measures.
  • • The idea of using the tool itself as a CI check was praised as a creative and potentially impactful approach to improving AI-driven workflows.
  • In summary, the discussion reflects a mix of optimism and caution regarding AI's role in automating software development processes, with thoughtful consideration of both its benefits and risks.

item.title: AI Agenda: AI Videos Nearly Indistinguishable From Real Videos, Runway Finds
item.description:
AI Agenda
Runway today is releasing its latest AI model, Gen-4.5, that can generate videos from an image. The model, from the startup that specializes in image and video-generating models, is impressive but is likely to underscore growing concerns about AI-generated deepfakes.͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 21, 2026

AI Agenda
By Rocket Drew
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! I’d love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign up here.

Hello! Rocket here.

Runway today is releasing its latest AI model, Gen-4.5, that can generate videos from an image. The model, from the startup that specializes in image and video-generating models, is impressive but is likely to underscore growing concerns about AI-generated deepfakes.

To measure the model’s performance, Runway asked over 1,000 people to distinguish real videos from similar videos generated by the model. Participants only guessed correctly 57.1% of the time—not much better than flipping a coin. 

Runway came up with the test when its own employees started having a hard time telling apart videos based on digital footage from the outputs of the new model, said Chief Technology Officer Anastasis Germanidis. “We have probably some of the most trained eyes,” he said, so if Runway’s employees were struggling with the task, they figured people who don’t spend their days scrutinizing AI videos would fare even worse.

Runway used its new model to generate a video from the starting frame of clips of real subjects, like animals and human faces. The clips came from Filmpac, a provider of video footage and other media. Runway then trimmed the real and AI videos to five seconds and made sure both had the same resolution.

Participants in the study had 10 seconds to guess whether a clip was real or AI-generated. The short time window is realistic, simulating how someone might encounter a video on social media.

Germanidis himself took a stab at it. The result? “I failed quite a bit,” he said. 

In the study, people did a better job on videos that contained human faces and hands, or humans taking actions. For those videos, accuracy ranged from 58% to 65%. It’s not that the model is worse at generating those videos: Germanidis thinks people are more attuned to videos of people that look “uncanny,” compared to other subjects.

Well before Runway’s latest model, lawmakers and some technologists were worried about the threat from deepfakes, or AI-generated videos and images that pretend to be legitimate. Those concerns intensified this month, after xAI’s Grok generated images of women and children wearing bikinis or lingerie, prompting bans in multiple countries and an investigation by the California attorney general.

To guard against misinformation, people should “have a more critical mindset” about the content they see online,” Germanidis said. “For us, the study is a way to kind of increase the awareness that at this point we’re crossing the threshold, and it’s hard to tell apart generated from real videos.”

Runway includes in the metadata of its videos that they are AI-generated and is also looking into more reliable ways to watermark these videos, so they can be identified as AI-generated, Germanidis said. Congress has proposed legislation to require watermarking of AI-generated content, and some states have passed laws requiring such disclosures. In Germanidis’ view, the technology is too early to codify specific requirements, but he noted that policies dealing with misinformation in general should cover AI-generated videos.

In the U.S., the 2024 presidential election came and went without significant disruption from AI-fueled disinformation, but Runway’s study is just the latest evidence that the quality of AI models has improved a lot over the past two years. With midterm elections coming up in November, our collective ability to sort fact from fiction will be tested again.

If you want to prepare in the meantime, anyone is free to try their hand at a Turing test on Runway’s website, where the company will be launching a version available to the public, along with a leaderboard to track who can most accurately determine what’s AI-generated and what’s not.

Here’s what else is going on…

People on the Move

Amazon has tapped former Microsoft executive Jigar Thakkar to lead Quick Suite, a collection of enterprise search and agent-building tools it launched in October as part of a broader push to develop compelling AI applications.

Greg Yang, a co-founder of xAI said in a post on X that he’s stepping back into an informal advisory role to go “founder mode” on his health, following a diagnosis for Lyme disease. “Until I pushed myself hard building xAI and weakened my immune system, the symptoms weren't noticeable.”

Overheard

“Don’t let your loved ones use ChatGPT,” Elon Musk posted on X on Tuesday, in reference to a post about ChatGPT users who committed suicide. The post followed another on Monday, in which Musk wrote “OpenAI’s ChatGPT convinced a guy to do a murder-suicide! To be safe, AI must be maximally truthful-seeking and not pander to delusions.”

In response, Altman wrote Tuesday that “we need to protect vulnerable users, while also making sure our guardrails still allow all of our users to benefit from our tools.” He also said that Musk had previously complained about ChatGPT’s moderation being too restrictive. “Apparently more than 50 people have died from crashes related to Autopilot. I only ever rode in a car using it once, some time ago, but my first thought was that it was far from a safe thing for Tesla to have released. I won’t even start on some of the Grok decisions,” Altman wrote.

Meanwhile, at Davos, Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis said he would be open to a détente in the AI race. In an interview with Bloomberg, Hassabis said would likely support a pause on AI development if every AI company agreed to it. He said he would like to see companies collaborate on AI development as they approach the creation of human-level AI, but unfortunately “international cooperation’s a little bit tricky at the moment.” Presumably, such a pause would also ease tensions between the CEOs of those companies on social media!

Policy Watch

Anthropic has hired three new lobbying firms since the beginning of December, Politico reported, citing recent disclosures. The firms are Thorn Run Partners, Kountoupes Denham Carr & Reid and Avenue Solutions.

Anthropic spent over $1 million in lobbying expenditures in the third quarter last year, Politico reported. That’s more than OpenAI spent in that period, but less than Meta or Amazon.

Deals and Debuts

See The Information’s Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

Zipline, a drone delivery startup, raised over $600 million at a $7.6 billion valuation, in a funding round from investors including Valor Equity Partners, Tiger Global, Fidelity Management and Research Company and Baillie Gifford.

Humans&, which is developing “human-centric” AI tools, raised $480 million at $4.48 billion valuation in a seed funding round led by SV Angel and co-founder Georges Harik, with participation from Nvidia, Jeff Bezos, GV, Emerson Collective, Forerunner, S32, DCVC, Human Capital, Felicis and CRV.

Baseten, which helps run AI models for companies including Cursor and Notion, raised $300 million at a $5 billion valuation in a funding round led by IVP and CapitalG, with participation from Nvidia, which invested $150 million, the Wall Street Journal reported.

OpenEvidence, which provides a “ChatGPT for doctors,” raised $250 million in funding at a $12 billion valuation led by Thrive Capital and DST Global. The Information first broke the round here.

Emergent, which provides AI for developing apps, raised $70 million in a Series B funding round at a $300 million valuation led by Khosla Ventures and SoftBank.

Applied Compute, which uses reinforcement learning to customize AI models, is in talks to raise up to $70 million at a $1.3 billion valuation, The Information reported. Kleiner Perkins is in talks to lead the round.

Datarails, which offers AI-powered FP&A software, raised $70 million in Series C funding led by One Peak.

Ivo, which uses AI to help lawyers review contracts, raised $55 million in a Series B funding round led by Blackbird.

Unbox Robotics, which develops warehouse robots, raised $28 million in a Series B funding round led by Icici Venture and Restart Labs.

OpenAI is asking a small group of advertisers for spending commitments of less than $1 million each over a several week trial period, as the company tests new ads within its ChatGPT chatbot, The Information reported.

OpenAI also began adding age verification to ChatGPT. If OpenAI estimates that a user is under 18, ChatGPT adds additional restrictions, including on violence and romantic roleplay.

ServiceNow has signed a multi-year deal to pay for OpenAI’s artificial intelligence models in its business software, the two companies said on Tuesday. Under the agreement, OpenAI will now be the “preferred” AI model provider in ServiceNow’s software. In the past, ServiceNow let customers choose between AI models from OpenAI or other providers including Google and Anthropic.

Amazon is open to working with other companies to run their AI shopping assistants on its site, where it already offers its own shopping chatbot, CEO Andy Jassy said in an interview with The Information’s Jessica Lessin at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

X released the algorithm it uses to recommend posts in users’ For You feeds. The algorithm ranks posts using “a Grok-based transformer model that predicts engagement probabilities for each post.”

72% of ChatGPT subscribers have set ChatGPT to their browser homepage, replacing traditional search engines, according to a survey conducted by Bango, a subscription bundling company.

Adobe released new AI features in Acrobat, such as the ability to generate podcast summaries based on files, create presentations and edit files using prompts.

A message from ServiceNow

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNow® works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more

New From Our Reporters

Exclusive

OpenAI Lines Up Advertisers, Reveals Key Details Ahead of Ads Launch

By Catherine Perloff and Sri Muppidi


Exclusive

Applied Compute, Founded by Ex-OpenAI Researchers, in Talks for $1.3 Billion Valuation

By Stephanie Palazzolo and Valida Pau


Exclusive

TikTok Plans Big Shopping Push

By Jing Yang and Juro Osawa

Recommended Newsletter

Every weekday, The Briefing helps executives get smarter about the latest in tech, media and finance. Subscribe for free now.

What We’re Reading

UK exposed to ‘serious harm’ by failure to tackle AI risks, MPs warn

Anthropic CEO Says AI Chip Sales to China Like Selling Nukes to North Korea

Ukraine to share wartime combat data with allies to help train AI

Opportunities

Group subscriptions

Empower your teams to stay ahead of market trends with the most trusted tech journalism.

Learn more


Brand partnerships

Reach The Information’s influential audience with your message.

Connect with our team

About AI Agenda

Stay ahead of the innovation and disruption happening in AI. Stephanie Palazzolo covers the tech, startups, companies and people making headlines.

Read the archives
Follow us

item.title: Thinking Machines implosion 🤖, Gemini Chrome Skills ⚡, Humans& $480M seed 💰
item.description:
Google DeepMind's CEO, Demis Hassabis, says that Chinese AI companies remain around six months behind the frontier AI of the leading Western labs ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR AI 2026-01-21

Agentic AI on the rise: Keys to unlocking value (Sponsor)

When it comes to your business, don't overlook AI agents and the broad set of tasks they can help with.  The latest tools can help drive innovation and we found a helpful eBook that explores how it's being done in the real world. 

Are you curious about AI agents that can reason, plan, and act to accomplish goals, with limited human involvement?

Agentic AI on the rise: Keys to unlocking value from AWS provides answers. Whether just getting started or ready to launch an AI agent today, you'll find guidance to simplify your AI agent journey. 

🚀

Headlines & Launches

DeepMind CEO Says Chinese AI Firms Are 6 Months Behind the West (3 minute read)

Google DeepMind's CEO, Demis Hassabis, says that Chinese AI companies remain around six months behind the frontier AI of the leading Western labs. He says the response to DeepSeek's R1 model last year was a massive overreaction and that while Chinese firms are very good at catching up to the frontier, they have yet to show they can innovate beyond that. Some of the barriers to Chinese AI development are set to come down as the Trump administration is easing a ban on advanced AI chip exports to China. Sales of the most advanced AI processors will remain blocked on national security grounds.
Gemini in Chrome is getting “Skills” as it moves toward becoming a full AI agent (2 minute read)

Gemini in Chrome is being upgraded into a proactive agent capable of performing complex tasks on users' behalf. A hidden internal page for 'skills' has been spotted in testing. The page features a dedicated interface where users can define specific capabilities for the AI. Skills will effectively allow users to 'teach' Gemini how to handle specific or repetitive workflows within the browser.
The Messy Human Drama That Dealt a Blow to One of AI's Hottest Startups (5 minute read)

Mira Murati says that Barret Zoph was fired from Thinking Machines Lab after repeated concerns about his conduct and lack of productivity. Zoph claims he was fired for expressing an intent to take a job elsewhere. Within hours of Zoph's firing, Zoph, another co-founder, and a third employee had signed offers to rejoin OpenAI. The departures are a sign of how the AI race is as much a battle for talent as technology.
AI startup Humans& raises $480 million at $4.5 billion valuation in seed round (2 minute read)

AI startup Humans& has secured $480 million in seed funding, reaching a $4.5 billion valuation. Key participants included Nvidia, Jeff Bezos, and GV. The company aims to develop human-centric AI for improved communication and collaboration. A product launch is expected early this year. The founding team consists of experts from OpenAI, Google DeepMind, and Meta.
🧠

Deep Dives & Analysis

Without Benchmarking LLMs, You're Likely Overpaying 5-10x (10 minute read)

Those paying for LLM APIs and have never tested alternatives are likely overpaying. There are almost always cheaper options with comparable quality for every workflow. Benchmarking and finding an optimal model is a complex process, but it can result in significant savings. This post discusses how one team navigated the process to save thousands of dollars.
The Tragedy of the Agentic Commons (14 minute read)

AI agents can improve matching markets, like dating or job searches, by using LLMs to convert unstructured preferences into actionable data, outperforming standard questionnaires. However, in markets where everyone uses AI agents, congestion increases significantly, reducing efficiency without a pricing mechanism. Introducing prices and institutional design can alleviate congestion, streamline coordination, and enhance market efficiency.
My agents are working. Are yours? (14 minute read)

AI agents are significantly increasing productivity by automating the analysis of thousands of research papers. A new anti-AI tool, Poison Fountain, corrupts AI training data to combat the perceived threat of machine intelligence.
🧑‍💻

Engineering & Research

Inworld releases new TTS model designed for the next wave of consumer AI applications (Sponsor)

Inworld released TTS-1.5, building on their #1-ranked position on the Artificial Analysis leaderboard. The new model achieves sub-250ms P90 latency, enabling natural conversation at thousands of queries per second. With 30% greater expressiveness, 40% lower word error rates, and 25x lower cost than alternatives, TTS-1.5 is designed for developers building high-demand, realtime applications at consumer scale.

Try TTS-1.5 Learn More

Introducing FastMCP 3.0 🚀 (11 minute read)

FastMCP 3.0 was built to be as durable as it is future-proof. It moves beyond simple tool servers and enters the era of Context Applications: rich, adaptive systems that manage the information flow to agents. FastMCP 3.0 can source components from anywhere, compose and transform them freely, personalize what each user sees, track state across sessions, and more. The first beta is available now.
RePo: Content-Aware Attention Reordering (18 minute read)

RePo is a module that repositions tokens based on contextual relevance rather than fixed order, improving long-range attention and robustness to noisy or structured inputs. The method draws on Cognitive Load Theory to justify reorganizing input structure for more efficient model processing.
Differential Transformer V2 (12 minute read)

DIFF V2 features key upgrades over DIFF V1: faster inference via compatibility with FlashAttention, better training stability by removing per-head RMSNorm, and a simplified λ parameterization that eliminates complex initialization schemes.
Waypoint-1: Real-time Interactive Video Diffusion from Overworld (5 minute read)

Waypoint-1 is a real-time-interactive video diffusion model. It can be controlled and prompted via text, mouse, and keyboard. Users can give the model some frames, run it, then have it create a world that they can interact with. They can move the camera freely with the mouse and input any key on the keyboard, all with zero latency. Each frame is generated with the controls as context. The model runs fast enough to provide a seamless experience, even on consumer hardware.
🎁

Miscellaneous

AI Gains Starting to Show in the Real Economy (6 minute read)

The introduction of AI tools like Claude Cowork and Alibaba's Qwen Assistant marks a shift towards AI's real-world applications, similar to ChatGPT's accessibility impact. Recent data from Q3 2025 shows a 4.9% productivity jump, with minimal change in hours worked, indicating potential initial AI-driven efficiency gains. Despite early-stage adoption, these developments could significantly boost economic productivity and eventually increase living standards.
Anthropic CEO: Selling H200s to China is like giving nukes to North Korea (4 minute read)

Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei has likened the decision to allow Nvidia to sell GPUs to Chinese companies to giving nuclear weapons to an adversary. The Trump administration announced just over a month ago that it would allow shipments of Nvidia H200 accelerators to Chinese customers as long as the US received 25% of the revenues. Chinese authorities have yet to allow local buyers to acquire the GPUs. Anthropic wants stricter controls on AI exports, saying access to the chips would put Chinese model developers in a better position to compete with the West.
⚡

Quick Links

TLDR is hiring a Senior Software Engineer, Applied AI ($200k-$300k, Fully Remote)

As the first engineer on TLDR's new Applied AI team, you'll build AI agents and composable Claude Skills to let non-technical teammates create their own AI workflows. Learn more.
Google says Gemini won't have ads, as ChatGPT prepares to add them (1 minute read)

While Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis has confirmed that Gemini won't get ads for now, Google has not confirmed that it will never add ads to Gemini.
Elon Musk says Tesla's restarted Dojo3 will be for ‘space-based AI compute' (3 minute read)

Tesla plans to restart its Dojo3 AI chip project focused on space-based AI compute.
ChatGPT Self Portrait (3 minute read)

ChatGPT's response to a prompt about user treatment often reflects the user's behavior and framing.
GLM-4.7-Flash (2 minute read)

GLM-4.7-Flash is a 30B-class MoE model designed for local deployment in coding, agent tasks, translation, and creative writing.
OpenAI Rolls Out Age Prediction in ChatGPT (3 minute read)

OpenAI introduced an age prediction model for ChatGPT consumer accounts to help apply teen-specific safety protections.
